[I]177-the nilghai shall do that to - morrow , for the sake of air and exercise . '[177-the nilghai]

' Bah ! '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick had barely time to throw up [his]147-dick arm and ward off the cushion that [the disgusted Torpenhow]156-torpenhow heaved at [his]156-torpenhow head .

' Air and exercise indeed , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai , sitting down heavily on [Dick]147-dick .

' Let 's give [him]147-dick a little of both . Get the bellows , [Torp]167-torp . '[177-the nilghai]

At this point the conference broke up in disorder , because [Dick]147-dick would not open [his]147-dick mouth till [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai held [his]147-dick nose fast , and there was some trouble in forcing the nozzle of the bellows between [his]147-dick teeth ; and even when it was there [he]147-dick weakly tried to puff against the force of the blast , and [his]147-dick cheeks blew up with a great explosion ; and [the enemy]561-the enemy becoming helpless with laughter [he]147-dick so beat [them]561-the enemy over the head with a soft sofa cushion that that became unsewn and distributed its feathers , and [Binkie]180-binkie , interfering in [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's interests , was bundled into the half - empty bag and advised to scratch [his]180-binkie way out , which [he]180-binkie did after a while , travelling rapidly up and down the floor in the shape of an agitated green haggis , and when [he]180-binkie came out looking for satisfaction , [the three pillars of [[his]180-binkie world]1226-his world]1225-the three pillars of his world were picking feathers out of [their]1225-the three pillars of his world hair .

' [A prophet]2862-a prophet has no honour in [[his]2862-a prophet own country]2863-his own country , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , ruefully , dusting [his]147-dick knees . ' [This filthy fluff]2864-this filthy fluff will never brush off [my]147-dick legs . '[147-dick]

' It was all for [your]147-dick own good , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai . ' Nothing like air and exercise . '[177-the nilghai]

' All for [your]147-dick good , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , not in the least with reference to past clowning . ' It would let [you]147-dick focus things at [their]2865-their proper worth and prevent [your]147-dick becoming slack in [this hothouse of [a town]2867-a town]2866-this hothouse of a town . Indeed it would , [old man]2243-old man . [I]156-torpenhow should n't have spoken if [I]156-torpenhow had n't thought so . Only , [you]147-dick make a joke of everything . '[156-torpenhow]

' Before [God]161-god [I]147-dick do no such thing , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , quickly and earnestly . ' [You]147-dick do n't know [me]147-dick if [you]147-dick think that . '[147-dick]

[I]0-i do n't think it , ' said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .[0-i]

' How can fellows like [ourselves]2869-ourselves , who know what life and death really mean , dare to make a joke of anything ? [I]0-i know [we]2869-ourselves pretend it , to save [ourselves]2869-ourselves from breaking down or going to the other extreme . Ca n't [I]0-i see , [old man]2243-old man , how [you]1227-you 're[0-i] always anxious about [me]0-i , and try to advise [me]0-i to make [my]0-i work better ? Do [you]1227-you suppose [I]0-i do n't think about that [myself]0-i ? But [you]1227-you ca n't help [me]0-i - [you]1227-you ca n't help [me]0-i - not even [you]1227-you . [I]0-i must play [my]0-i own hand alone in [my]0-i own way . '[0-i]

' Hear , hear , '[177-the nilghai] from [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' What 's the one thing in the Nilghai Saga that [I]147-dick 've never drawn in the Nungapunga Book ? '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick continued to [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , who was a little astonished at the outburst .

Now there was one blank page in the book given over to the sketch that [Dick]147-dick had not drawn of the crowning exploit in [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai 's life ; when [that man]2272-that man , being young and forgetting that [his]2272-that man body and bones belonged to the paper that employed [him]2272-that man , had ridden over sunburned slippery grass in the rear of [[Bredow]233-bredow 's brigade]1229-bredow 's brigade on the day that [the troopers]1230-the troopers flung [themselves]1230-the troopers at [[Caurobert]234-caurobert 's artillery]1231-caurobert 's artillery , and for aught [they]1230-the troopers knew twenty battalions in front , to save [the battered 24th German Infantry]1232-the battered 24th german infantry , to give time to decide the fate of [Vionville]91-vionville , and to learn ere [[their]1230-the troopers remnant]1233-their remnant came back to [Flavigay]92-flavigay that [cavalry]1234-cavalry can attack and crumple and break [unshaken infantry]1235-unshaken infantry . Whenever [he]2272-that man was inclined to think over a life that might have been better , an income that might have been larger , and a soul that might have been considerably cleaner , [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai would comfort [himself]2272-that man with the thought , ' [I]2272-that man rode with [[Bredow]233-bredow 's brigade at [Vionville]91-vionville]2871-bredow 's brigade at vionville , '[2272-that man] and take heart for any lesser battle the next day might bring .

' [I]2272-that man know , '[2272-that man] [he]2272-that man said very gravely . ' [I]2272-that man was always glad that [you]0-i left it out . '[2272-that man]

' [I]177-the nilghai left it out because [Nilghai]177-the nilghai taught [me]177-the nilghai what [the Germany army]2872-the germany army learned then , and what [Schmidt]235-schmidt taught [[their]2872-the germany army cavalry]2873-their cavalry . [I]177-the nilghai do n't know German .[177-the nilghai]

What is it ? " Take care of the time and the dressing will take care of itself . " [I]0-i must ride [my]0-i own line to [my]0-i own beat , [old man]2243-old man . '[0-i]

' Tempe ist richtung . [You]0-i 've learned [your]0-i lesson well , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' [He]0-i must go alone . [He]0-i speaks truth , [Torp]167-torp . '[0-i]

' Maybe [I]0-i 'm[0-i] as wrong as [I]0-i can be - hideously wrong . [I]0-i must find that out for [myself]0-i , as [I]0-i have to think things out for [myself]0-i , but [I]0-i dare n't turn [my]0-i head to dress by [the next man]1237-the next man . It hurts [me]0-i a great deal more than [you]1238-you know not to be able to go , but [I]0-i can not , that 's all . [I]0-i must do [my]0-i own work and live [my]0-i own life in [my]0-i own way , because [I]0-i 'm responsible for both .[167-torp]

Only do n't think [I]0-i frivol about it , [Torp]167-torp . [I]0-i have [my]0-i own matches and sulphur , and [I]0-i 'll make [my]0-i own hell , thanks . '[0-i]

There was an uncomfortable pause . Then [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow said blandly , ' What did [the Governor of [North Carolina]93-north carolina]2874-the governor of north carolina say to [the Governor of [South Carolina]94-south carolina]2875-the governor of south carolina ? '[156-torpenhow]

' Excellent notion . It is a long time between drinks . There are the makings of [a very fine prig]2876-a very fine prig in [you]167-torp , [Dick]147-dick , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' [I]147-dick 've liberated [my]147-dick mind , estimable [Binkie]180-binkie , with the feathers in [his]180-binkie mouth . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick picked up [the still indignant one]1239-the still indignant one and shook [him]1239-the still indignant one tenderly .

' [You]180-binkie 're[147-dick] tied up in a sack and made to run about blind , [Binkie]180-binkie - wee , without any reason , and it has hurt [your]180-binkie little feelings . Never mind . Sic volo , sic jubeo , stet pro ratione voluntas , and do n't sneeze in [my]0-i eye because [I]0-i talk Latin . Good - night . '[147-dick]

[He]147-dick went out of [the room]397-the room .

' That 's distinctly one for [you]167-torp , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai . ' [I]177-the nilghai told [you]167-torp it was hopeless to meddle with [him]180-binkie . [He]180-binkie 's not pleased . '[177-the nilghai]

' [He]180-binkie 'd swear at [me]156-torpenhow if [he]180-binkie were n't . [I]156-torpenhow ca n't make it out . [He]180-binkie has the go - fever upon [him]180-binkie and [he]180-binkie wo n't go . [I]156-torpenhow only hope that [he]180-binkie may n't have to go some day when [he]180-binkie does n't want to , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

In [[his]147-dick own room]1241-his own room [Dick]147-dick was settling a question with [himself]147-dick - and the question was whether [all the world]1242-all the world , and all that was therein , and a burning desire to exploit both , was worth one threepenny piece thrown into [the Thames]41-the thames .

' It came of seeing [the sea]2168-the sea , and [I]177-the nilghai 'm[177-the nilghai] a cur to think about it , ' [he]177-the nilghai decided .[177-the nilghai]

' After all , the honeymoon will be that tour - with reservations ; only ... only [I]177-the nilghai did n't realise that [the sea]2168-the sea was so strong . [I]177-the nilghai did n't feel it so much when [I]177-the nilghai was with [Maisie]146-maisie . These damnable songs did it . [He]147-dick 's beginning again . '[177-the nilghai]

But it was only [Herrick]236-herrick 's Nightpiece to [Julia]237-julia that [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai sang , and before it was ended [Dick]147-dick reappeared on the threshold , not altogether clothed indeed , but in [his]147-dick right mind , thirsty and at peace .

The mood had come and gone with the rising and the falling of the tide by [Fort Keeling]2-fort keeling .

CHAPTER IX

' If [I]2429-the red - haired girl have taken the common clay And wrought it cunningly In the shape of a god that was digged a clod , The greater honour to [me]2429-the red - haired girl . '[2429-the red - haired girl]

' If [thou]2429-the red - haired girl hast taken the common clay , And [thy]2429-the red - haired girl hands be not free From the taint of the soil , [thou]2429-the red - haired girl hast made [thy]2429-the red - haired girl spoil The greater shame to [thee]2429-the red - haired girl . '[1243-the two potters] - [The Two Potters]1243-the two potters . [HE]147-dick DID no work of any kind for the rest of the week . Then came another Sunday . [He]147-dick dreaded and longed for the day always , but since [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl had sketched [him]147-dick there was rather more dread than desire in [his]147-dick mind .

[He]147-dick found that [Maisie]146-maisie had entirely neglected [his]147-dick suggestions about line - work . [She]146-maisie had gone off at score filed with some absurd notion for a ' fancy head . '[146-maisie] It cost [Dick]147-dick something to command [his]147-dick temper .

' What 's the good of suggesting anything ? '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said pointedly .

' Ah , but this will be a picture , - a real picture ; and [I]147-dick know that [Kami]174-kami will let [me]147-dick send it to [the Salon]2417-the salon . [You]147-dick do n't mind , do [you]147-dick ? '[147-dick]

' [I]146-maisie suppose not . But [you]147-dick wo n't have time for the Salon . '[146-maisie]

[Maisie]146-maisie hesitated a little . [She]146-maisie even felt uncomfortable .

' [We]2880-we 're[146-maisie] going over to [France]3-france a month sooner because of it . [I]0-i shall get the idea sketched out here and work it up at [Kami]174-kami 's .

[Dick]147-dick 's heart stood still , and [he]147-dick came very near to being disgusted with [[his]147-dick queen]1245-his queen who could do no wrong . ' Just when [I]1245-his queen thought [I]1245-his queen had made some headway , [she]1245-his queen goes off chasing butterflies . It 's too maddening ! '[1245-his queen]

There was no possibility of arguing , for [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl was in [the studio]712-the studio . [Dick]147-dick could only look unutterable reproach .

' [I]1248-the red - haired girl behind him 'm[1248-the red - haired girl behind him] sorry , ' [he]1248-the red - haired girl behind him said , '[1248-the red - haired girl behind him] and [I]0-i think [you]2429-the red - haired girl make a mistake . But what 's the idea of [your]2429-the red - haired girl new picture ? '[147-dick]

' [I]147-dick took it from a book . '[147-dick]

' That 's bad , to begin with . Books are n't the places for pictures . And - - '[147-dick]

' It 's this , '[1248-the red - haired girl behind him] said [the red - haired girl behind [him]147-dick]1248-the red - haired girl behind him . ' [I]1248-the red - haired girl behind him was reading it to [Maisie]146-maisie the other day from [The City of Dreadful Night]2881-the city of dreadful night . D'you know the book ? '[1248-the red - haired girl behind him]

' A little . [I]147-dick am sorry [I]147-dick spoke . There are pictures in it . What has taken [her]1245-his queen fancy ? '[147-dick]

' The description of the Melancolia -[1248-the red - haired girl behind him]

' [Her]1245-his queen folded wings as of a mighty eagle , But all too impotent to lift the regal Robustness of [her]1245-his queen earth - born strength and pride . And here again . [Maisie]146-maisie , get the tea , [dear]2419-dear .[147-dick]

' The forehead charged with baleful thoughts and dreams , The household bunch of keys , [the housewife]2883-the housewife 's gown , Voluminous indented , and yet rigid As though a shell of burnished metal frigid , [Her]1245-his queen feet thick - shod to tread all weakness down . '[1248-the red - haired girl behind him] There was no attempt to conceal the scorn of the lazy voice . [Dick]147-dick winced .

' But that has been done already by [an obscure artist by the name of Durer]2884-an obscure artist by the name of durer , '[147-dick] said [he]147-dick . ' How does the poem run ? -[147-dick]

' Three centuries and threescore years ago , With phantasies of [his]147-dick peculiar thought .[147-dick]

[You]1249-you might as well try to rewrite [Hamlet]238-hamlet . It will be a waste of time .

' No , it wo n't , '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie , putting down the teacups with a clatter to reassure [herself]146-maisie . ' And [I]146-maisie mean to do it . Ca n't [you]147-dick see what a beautiful thing it would make ? '[146-maisie]

' How in perdition can [one]727-one do work when one has n't had the proper training ? [Any fool]2886-any fool can get a notion . It needs training to drive the thing through , - training and conviction ; not rushing after the first fancy . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick spoke between [his]147-dick teeth .

' [You]147-dick do n't understand , '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie . ' [I]146-maisie think [I]146-maisie can do it . '[146-maisie]

Again the voice of [the girl behind [him]147-dick]1250-the girl behind him -

' Baffled and beaten back , [she]1250-the girl behind him works on still ; Weary and sick of soul , [she]1250-the girl behind him works the more . Sustained by [her]1250-the girl behind him indomitable will , The hands shall fashion , and the brain shall pore , And all [her]1250-the girl behind him sorrow shall be turned to labour - - [I]1250-the girl behind him fancy [Maisie]146-maisie means to embody [herself]146-maisie in the picture . '[1250-the girl behind him]

' Sitting on a throne of rejected pictures ? No , [I]1250-the girl behind him sha n't , [dear]2419-dear . The notion in itself has fascinated [me]1250-the girl behind him . - Of course [you]147-dick do n't care for fancy heads , [Dick]147-dick .[1250-the girl behind him]

[I]0-i do n't think [you]147-dick could do them . [You]147-dick like blood and bones . '[147-dick]

[Dick]147-dick went into [the street]781-the street , and was rapturously received by [Binkie]180-binkie .

' [We]1380-we 've got it very badly , [little dog]2994-little dog ! Just as badly as [we]1380-we can get it . [We]1380-we 'll go to [the Park]812-the park to think it out . '[1380-we]

[They]1380-we headed for a certain tree that [Dick]147-dick knew well , and [they]1380-we sat down to thin , because [his]147-dick legs were trembling under [him]147-dick and there was cold fear at the pit of [his]147-dick stomach .

' How could it have come without any warning ? It 's as sudden as being shot . It 's the living death , [Binkie]180-binkie . [We]1380-we 're[180-binkie] to be shut up in the dark in one year if [we]1380-we 're careful , and [we]1380-we sha n't see [anybody]877-anybody , and [we]1380-we shall never have anything [we]1380-we want , not though [we]1380-we live to be a hundred ! '[180-binkie] [Binkie]180-binkie wagged [his]180-binkie tail joyously . ' [Binkie]180-binkie , [we]1380-we must think . Let 's see how it feels to be blind . '[180-binkie] [Dick]147-dick shut [his]147-dick eyes , and flaming commas and Catherine - wheels floated inside the lids . Yet when [he]147-dick looked across [the Park]812-the park the scope of [his]147-dick vision was not contracted . [He]147-dick could see perfectly , until a procession of slow - wheeling fireworks defiled across [his]147-dick eyeballs .

' [Little dorglums]253-little dorglums , [we]1380-we are n't at all well . Let 's go [home]2172-home . If only [Torp]167-torp were back , now ! '[177-the nilghai]

But [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow was in [the south of [England]18-england]1382-the south of england , inspecting [[dockyards]1383-dockyards in the company of [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai]1384-dockyards in the company of the nilghai . [His]156-torpenhow letters were brief and full of mystery .

[Dick]147-dick had never asked [anybody]877-anybody to help [him]156-torpenhow in [his]156-torpenhow joys or [his]156-torpenhow sorrows . [He]147-dick argued , in the loneliness of [[his]147-dick studio]2374-his studio , henceforward to be decorated with a film of gray gauze in one corner , that , if [his]156-torpenhow fate were blindness , [all the Torpenhows in [the world]327-the world]1387-all the torpenhows in the world could not save [him]156-torpenhow . ' [I]147-dick ca n't call [him]156-torpenhow off [his]156-torpenhow trip to sit down and sympathise with [me]147-dick . [I]147-dick must pull through this business alone , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said . [He]147-dick was lying on the sofa , eating [his]147-dick moustache and wondering what the darkness of the night would be like . Then came to [his]147-dick mind the memory of a quaint scene in [the Soudan]45-the soudan . [A soldier]1389-a soldier had been nearly hacked in two by a broad - bladed Arab spear . For one instant [the man]493-the man felt no pain . Looking down , [he]147-dick saw that [his]493-the man life - blood was going from [him]493-the man . The stupid bewilderment on [his]493-the man face was so intensely comic that both [Dick]147-dick and [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , still panting and unstrung from a fight for life , had roared with laughter , in which [the man]493-the man seemed as if [he]493-the man would join , but , as [his]493-the man lips parted in a sheepish grin , the agony of death came upon [him]493-the man , and [he]493-the man pitched grunting at [their]1392-we feet . [Dick]147-dick laughed again , remembering the horror . It seemed so exactly like [his]147-dick own case .

' But [I]147-dick have a little more time allowed [me]147-dick , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said . [He]147-dick paced up and down [the room]397-the room , quietly at first , but afterwards with the hurried feet of fear . It was as though a black shadow stood at [his]147-dick elbow and urged [him]147-dick to go forward ; and there were only weaving circles and floating pin - dots before [his]147-dick eyes .

' [We]1392-we need to be calm , [Binkie]180-binkie ; [we]1392-we must be calm . '[147-dick] [He]147-dick talked aloud for the sake of distraction . ' This is n't nice at all . What shall [we]1392-we do ? [We]1392-we must do something . [Our]1392-we time is short . [I]147-dick should n't have believed that this morning ; but now things are different . [Binkie]180-binkie , where was [Moses]254-moses when the light went out ? '[147-dick]

[Binkie]180-binkie smiled from ear to ear , as [a well - bred terrier]1394-a well - bred terrier should , but made no suggestion .

' " Were there but world enough and time , [This coyness]2998-this coyness , [Binkie]180-binkie , were not crime .... But at [my]147-dick back [I]147-dick always hear - - " '[147-dick] [He]147-dick wiped [his]147-dick forehead , which was unpleasantly damp . ' What can [I]147-dick do ? What can [I]147-dick do ? [I]147-dick have n't any notions left , and [I]147-dick ca n't think connectedly , but [I]147-dick must do something , or [I]147-dick shall go off [my]147-dick head . '[147-dick]

The hurried walk recommenced , [Dick]147-dick stopping every now and again to drag forth long - neglected canvases and old note - books ; for [he]147-dick turned to [his]147-dick work by instinct , as a thing that could not fail . ' [You]147-dick wo n't do , and [you]147-dick wo n't do , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said , at each inspection . ' [No more soldiers]2999-no more soldiers . [I]147-dick could n't paint 'em[147-dick] . Sudden death comes [home]2172-home too nearly , and this is battle and murder for [me]0-i . '[147-dick]

The day was failing , and [Dick]147-dick thought for a moment that the twilight of the blind had come upon [him]147-dick unaware . ' [Allah Almighty]196-allah ! '[147-dick] [he]147-dick cried despairingly , ' help [me]147-dick through the time of waiting , and [I]147-dick wo n't whine when [my]147-dick punishment comes . What can [I]147-dick do now , before the light goes ? '[147-dick]

There was no answer . [Dick]147-dick waited till [he]147-dick could regain some sort of control over [himself]147-dick . [His]147-dick hands were shaking , and [he]147-dick prided [himself]147-dick on their steadiness ; [he]147-dick could feel that [his]147-dick lips were quivering , and the sweat was running down [his]147-dick face . [He]147-dick was lashed by fear , driven forward by the desire to get to work at once and accomplish something , and maddened by the refusal of [his]147-dick brain to do more than repeat the news that [he]147-dick was about to go blind . ' It 's a humiliating exhibition , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick thought , ' and [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] glad [Torp]167-torp is n't here to see . [The doctor]579-the doctor said [I]0-i was to avoid mental worry .

Come here and let [me]0-i pet [you]1397-you , [Binkie]180-binkie . '[180-binkie]

[The little dog]1132-the little dog yelped because [Dick]147-dick nearly squeezed the bark out of [him]1132-the little dog .

Then [he]180-binkie heard [the man speaking in the twilight]1399-the man speaking in the twilight , and , doglike , understood that [his]147-dick trouble stood off from [him]147-dick - ' [Allah]196-allah is good , [Binkie]180-binkie . Not quite so gentle as [we]3000-we could wish , but [we]3000-we 'll discuss that later . [I]147-dick think [I]147-dick see [my]147-dick way to it now . All those studies of [Bessie]244-bessie 's head were nonsense , and they nearly brought [[your]1397-you master]3001-your master into a scrape . [I]147-dick hold the notion now as clear as crystal , - " the Melancolia that transcends all wit . " There shall be [Maisie]146-maisie in that head , because [I]147-dick shall never get [Maisie]146-maisie ; and [Bess]255-bess , of course , because [she]255-bess knows all about [Melancolia]246-the melancolia , though [she]255-bess does n't know [she]255-bess knows ; and there shall be some drawing in it , and it shall all end up with a laugh . That 's for [myself]147-dick . Shall [she]146-maisie giggle or grin ? No , [she]146-maisie shall laugh right out of the canvas , and [every man]1221-every man and woman that ever had a sorrow of [their]1221-every man own shall - what is it the poem says ? -[147-dick]

' Understand the speech and feel a stir Of fellowship in all disastrous fight . " In all disastrous fight " ? That 's better than painting the thing merely to pique [Maisie]146-maisie . [I]180-binkie can do it now because [I]180-binkie have it inside [me]180-binkie . [Binkie]180-binkie , [I]180-binkie 'm[180-binkie] going to hold [you]1400-you up by [your]1400-you tail . [You]1400-you 're [an omen]3003-an omen . Come here . '[1400-you]

[Binkie]180-binkie swung head downward for a moment without speaking .

' Rather like holding a guinea - pig ; but [you]1400-you 're[180-binkie] a brave little dog , and [you]1400-you do n't yelp when [you]1400-you 're hung up . It is an omen . '[1400-you]

[Binkie]180-binkie went to [his]180-binkie own chair , and as often as [he]180-binkie looked saw [Dick]147-dick walking up and down , rubbing [his]147-dick hands and chuckling . That night [Dick]147-dick wrote a letter to [Maisie]146-maisie full of the tenderest regard for [her]146-maisie health , but saying very little about [his]147-dick own , and dreamed of the Melancolia to be born . Not till morning did [he]147-dick remember that something might happen to [him]147-dick in the future .

[He]147-dick fell to work , whistling softly , and was swallowed up in the clean , clear joy of creation , which does not come to [man]2294-man too often , lest [he]147-dick should consider [himself]147-dick [the equal of [[his]147-dick God]321-his god]1402-the equal of his god , and so refuse to die at the appointed time . [He]147-dick forgot [Maisie]146-maisie , [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , and [Binkie]180-binkie at [his]147-dick feet , but remembered to stir [Bessie]244-bessie , who needed very little stirring , into a tremendous rage , that [he]147-dick might watch the smouldering lights in [her]244-bessie eyes .

[He]147-dick threw [himself]147-dick without reservation into [his]147-dick work , and did not think of the doom that was to overtake [him]147-dick , for [he]147-dick was possessed with [his]147-dick notion , and the things of [this world]1404-this world had no power upon [him]147-dick .

' [You]147-dick 're[147-dick] pleased to - day , ' said [Bessie]244-bessie .[147-dick]

[Dick]147-dick waved [his]147-dick mahl - stick in mystic circles and went to the sideboard for a drink . In the evening , when the exaltation of the day had died down , [he]147-dick went to the sideboard again , and after some visits became convinced that [the eye - doctor]1405-the eye - doctor was [a liar]1406-a liar , since [he]147-dick could still see everything very clearly .

[He]147-dick was of opinion that [he]147-dick would even make a home for [Maisie]146-maisie , and that whether [she]146-maisie liked it or not [she]146-maisie should be [[his]147-dick wife]2793-his wife . The mood passed next morning , but the sideboard and all upon it remained for [his]147-dick comfort .

Again [he]147-dick set to work , and [his]147-dick eyes troubled [him]147-dick with spots and dashes and blurs till [he]147-dick had taken counsel with the sideboard , and the Melancolia both on the canvas and in [his]147-dick own mind appeared lovelier than ever . There was a delightful sense of irresponsibility upon [him]147-dick , such as [they]1408-they feel who walking among [[their]1408-they fellow - men]1409-their fellow - men know that the death - sentence of disease is upon [them]1408-they , and , seeing that fear is but waste of the little time left , are riotously happy . The days passed without event .

[Bessie]244-bessie arrived punctually always , and , though [her]244-bessie voice seemed to [Dick]147-dick to come from a distance , [her]244-bessie face was always very near . The Melancolia began to flame on the canvas , in the likeness of [a woman who had known all the sorrow in [the world]327-the world and was laughing at it]1410-a woman who had known all the sorrow in the world and was laughing at it . It was true that the corners of [the studio]712-the studio draped themselves in gray film and retired into the darkness , that the spots in [his]147-dick eyes and the pains across [his]147-dick head were very troublesome , and that [Maisie]146-maisie 's letters were hard to read and harder still to answer . [He]147-dick could not tell [her]244-bessie of [his]147-dick trouble , and [he]147-dick could not laugh at [her]244-bessie accounts of [her]244-bessie own Melancolia which was always going to be finished . But the furious days of toil and the nights of wild dreams made amends for all , and the sideboard was [[his]147-dick best friend on [earth]332-earth]1413-his best friend on earth .

[Bessie]244-bessie was singularly dull . [She]244-bessie used to shriek with rage when [Dick]147-dick stared at [her]244-bessie between half - closed eyes . Now [she]244-bessie sulked , or watched [him]147-dick with disgust , saying very little .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow had been absent for six weeks . An incoherent note heralded [his]156-torpenhow return . ' News ! great news ! '[147-dick] [he]147-dick wrote . ' [The Nilghai]177-the nilghai knows , and so does [the Keneu]3004-the keneu . [We]3005-we 're[147-dick] all back on Thursday . Get lunch and clean [your]156-torpenhow accoutrements . '[147-dick]

[Dick]147-dick showed [Bessie]244-bessie the letter , and [she]244-bessie abused [him]147-dick for that [he]147-dick had ever sent [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow away and ruined [her]244-bessie life .

' Well , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , brutally , ' [you]156-torpenhow 're[147-dick] better as [you]156-torpenhow are , instead of making love to [some drunken beast in [the street]781-the street]1415-some drunken beast in the street . ' [He]147-dick felt that [he]147-dick had rescued [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow from great temptation .[1415-some drunken beast in the street]

' [I]0-i do n't know if that 's any worse than sitting to a drunken beast in [a studio]3006-a studio . [You]156-torpenhow have n't been sober for three weeks . [You]156-torpenhow 've been soaking the whole time ; and yet [you]156-torpenhow pretend [you]156-torpenhow 're[0-i] better than [me]0-i ! '[0-i]

' What d'you mean ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick .

' Mean ! [You]156-torpenhow 'll see when [Mr. Torpenhow]156-torpenhow comes back . '[0-i]

It was not long to wait . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow met [Bessie]244-bessie on [the staircase]783-the staircase without a sign of feeling . [He]156-torpenhow had news that was more to [him]156-torpenhow than many [Bessies]256-bessies , and [the Keneu]183-the keneu and [the Nilghai]2383-the nilghai were trampling behind [him]156-torpenhow , calling for [Dick]147-dick .

' Drinking like a fish , '[244-bessie] [Bessie]244-bessie whispered . ' [He]147-dick 's been at it for nearly a month . '[244-bessie] [She]244-bessie followed [the men]528-the men stealthily to hear judgment done .

[They]528-the men came into [the studio]712-the studio , rejoicing , to be welcomed over effusively by [a drawn , lined , shrunken , haggard wreck]1421-a drawn , lined , shrunken , haggard wreck , - unshaven , blue - white about the nostrils , stooping in the shoulders , and peering under [his]156-torpenhow eyebrows nervously . The drink had been at work as steadily as [Dick]147-dick .

' Is this [you]156-torpenhow ? '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

' All that 's left of [me]156-torpenhow . Sit down . [Binkie]180-binkie 's quite well , and [I]156-torpenhow 've been doing some good work . '[156-torpenhow] [He]156-torpenhow reeled where [he]156-torpenhow stood .

' [You]156-torpenhow 've done some of the worst work [you]156-torpenhow 've ever done in [your]156-torpenhow life . [Man alive]3007-man alive , [you]156-torpenhow 're[156-torpenhow] - - '[156-torpenhow]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow turned to [[his]156-torpenhow companions]1066-his companions appealingly , and [they]528-the men left [the room]397-the room to find lunch elsewhere . Then [he]156-torpenhow spoke ; but , since the reproof of [a friend]2599-a friend is much too sacred and intimate a thing to be printed , and since [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow used figures and metaphors which were unseemly , and contempt untranslatable , it will never be known what was actually said to [Dick]147-dick , who blinked and winked and picked at [his]147-dick hands . After a time [the culprit]1425-the culprit began to feel the need of a little self - respect . [He]1425-the culprit was quite sure that [he]1425-the culprit had not in any way departed from virtue , and there were reasons , too , of which [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow knew nothing . [He]156-torpenhow would explain .

[He]156-torpenhow rose , tried to straighten [his]156-torpenhow shoulders , and spoke to the face [he]156-torpenhow could hardly see .

' [You]156-torpenhow are right , '[156-torpenhow] [he]156-torpenhow said . ' But [I]1426-i am right , too . After [you]156-torpenhow went away [I]1426-i had some trouble with [my]1426-i eyes . So [I]1426-i went to [an oculist]2986-an oculist , and [he]2986-an oculist turned a gasogene - [I]1426-i mean a gas - engine - into [my]1426-i eye . That was very long ago . [He]1426-i said , " Scar on the head , - sword - cut and optic nerve . " Make a note of that . So [I]1426-i am going blind . [I]1426-i have some work to do before [I]1426-i go blind , and [I]1426-i suppose that [I]1426-i must do it . [I]1426-i can not see much now , but [I]1426-i can see best when [I]1426-i am drunk . [I]1426-i did not know [I]1426-i was drunk till [I]1426-i was told , but [I]1426-i must go on with [my]1426-i work . If [you]147-dick want to see it , there it is . '[1426-i] [He]1426-i pointed to the all but finished Melancolia and looked for applause .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow said nothing , and [Dick]147-dick began to whimper feebly , for joy at seeing [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow again , for grief at misdeeds - if indeed they were misdeeds - that made [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow remote and unsympathetic , and for childish vanity hurt , since [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow had not given a word of praise to [his]156-torpenhow wonderful picture .

[Bessie]244-bessie looked through the keyhole after a long pause , and saw [the two walking up and down as usual]1427-the two walking up and down as usual , [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's hand on [Dick]147-dick 's shoulder .

Hereat [she]244-bessie said something so improper that it shocked even [Binkie]180-binkie , who was dribbling patiently on the landing with the hope of seeing [[his]180-binkie master]1428-his master again .

[CHAPTER XI]257-chapter xi

[The lark]1429-the lark will make [her]1429-the lark hymn to [God]161-god , [The partridge]1430-the partridge call [her]1429-the lark brood , While [I]0-i forget the heath [I]0-i trod , [The fields wherein [I]0-i stood]1431-the fields wherein i stood .

' Tis dule to know not night from morn , But deeper dule to know [I]1429-the lark can but hear [the hunter]3009-the hunter 's horn That once [I]1429-the lark used to blow .[1429-the lark]

- [The Only Son]1432-the only son . IT WAS the third day after [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's return , and [his]1432-the only son heart was heavy .

' Do [you]147-dick mean to tell [me]1429-the lark that [you]147-dick ca n't see to work without whiskey ? It 's generally the other way about . '[1429-the lark]

' Can [a drunkard]3010-a drunkard swear on [his]3010-a drunkard honour ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick .

' Yes , if [he]3010-a drunkard has been as good a man as [you]147-dick . '[1429-the lark]

' Then [I]147-dick give [you]147-dick [my]147-dick word of honour , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , speaking hurriedly through parched lips . ' [Old man]2243-old man , [I]147-dick can hardly see [your]147-dick face now . [You]147-dick 've kept [me]147-dick sober for two days , - if [I]147-dick ever was drunk , - and [I]147-dick 've done no work .[147-dick]

Do n't keep [me]0-i back any more . [I]0-i do n't know when [my]0-i eyes may give out .

The spots and dots and the pains and things are crowding worse than ever . [I]0-i swear [I]0-i can see all right when [I]0-i 'm - when [I]1433-i 'm[1433-i] moderately screwed , as [you]1433-i say . Give [me]0-i three more sittings from [Bessie]244-bessie and all - the stuff [I]0-i want , and the picture will be done . [I]0-i ca n't kill [myself]0-i in three days . It only means a touch of D. T. at the worst . '[1433-i]

' If [I]1433-i give [you]147-dick three days more will [you]147-dick promise [me]1433-i to stop work and - the other thing , whether the picture 's finished or not ? '[1433-i]

' [I]1433-i ca n't . [You]147-dick do n't know what that picture means to [me]1433-i . But surely [you]147-dick could get [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai to help [you]147-dick , and knock [me]1433-i down and tie [me]1433-i up . [I]1433-i should n't fight for the whiskey , but [I]1433-i should for the work . '[1433-i]

' Go on , then . [I]0-i give [you]147-dick three days ; but [you]147-dick 're[0-i] nearly breaking [my]0-i heart . '[0-i]

[Dick]147-dick returned to [his]147-dick work , toiling as [one possessed]1434-one possessed ; and [the yellow devil of whiskey]1435-the yellow devil of whiskey stood by [him]147-dick and chased away the spots in [his]147-dick eyes . [The Melancolia]246-the melancolia was nearly finished , and was all or nearly all that [he]147-dick had hoped [she]246-the melancolia would be . [Dick]147-dick jested with [Bessie]244-bessie , who reminded [him]147-dick that [he]147-dick was ' a drunken beast '[244-bessie] ; but the reproof did not move [him]147-dick .

' [You]147-dick ca n't understand , [Bess]255-bess . [We]3012-we are in sight of [land]3013-land now , and soon [we]3012-we shall lie back and think about what [we]3012-we 've done . [I]147-dick 'll give [you]147-dick three months '[147-dick] pay when the picture 's finished , and next time [I]0-i have any more work in hand - but that does n't matter . Wo n't three months ' pay make [you]147-dick hate [me]244-bessie less ? '[244-bessie]

' No , it wo n't ! [I]244-bessie hate [you]147-dick , and [I]244-bessie 'll go on hating [you]147-dick . [Mr. Torpenhow]156-torpenhow wo n't speak to [me]244-bessie any more . [He]156-torpenhow 's always looking at maps . '[244-bessie]

[Bessie]244-bessie did not say that [she]244-bessie had again laid siege to [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , or that at the end of [our]1436-our passionate pleading [he]156-torpenhow had picked [her]244-bessie up , given [her]244-bessie a kiss , and put [her]244-bessie outside the door with the recommendation not to be [a little fool]1437-a little fool . [He]156-torpenhow spent most of [his]156-torpenhow time in [the company of [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai]1438-the company of the nilghai , and [their]1439-we talk was of war in the near future , the hiring of [transports]1440-transports , and secret preparations among [the dockyards]1441-the dockyards . [He]156-torpenhow did not wish to see [Dick]147-dick till the picture was finished .

' [He]147-dick 's doing first - class work , '[156-torpenhow] [he]156-torpenhow said to [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai , ' and it 's quite out of [his]147-dick regular line . But , for the matter of that , so 's [his]147-dick infernal soaking . '[156-torpenhow]

' Never mind . Leave [him]147-dick alone . When [he]147-dick has come to [his]147-dick senses again [we]1439-we 'll carry [him]147-dick off from [this place]2279-this place and let [him]147-dick breathe clean air . [Poor Dick]147-dick ! [I]147-dick do n't envy [you]156-torpenhow , [Torp]167-torp , when [his]147-dick eyes fail . '[147-dick]

' Yes , it will be a case of " God help [the man who 's chained to [our]1439-we Davie]3015-the man who 's chained to our davie . In the afternoon of the third day [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow heard [Dick]147-dick calling for [him]156-torpenhow .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow gave [her]244-bessie a check and went to [[his]156-torpenhow own rooms]1446-his own rooms . [Bessie]244-bessie faithfully tidied up [the studio]712-the studio , set the door ajar for flight , emptied half a bottle of turpentine on a duster , and began to scrub the face of the Melancolia viciously . The paint did not smudge quickly enough . [She]244-bessie took a palette - knife and scraped , following each stroke with the wet duster . In five minutes the picture was a formless , scarred muddle of colours . [She]244-bessie threw the paint - stained duster into [the studio]712-the studio stove , stuck out [her]244-bessie tongue at the sleeper , and whispered , ' Bilked ! '[244-bessie] as [she]244-bessie turned to run down [the staircase]783-the staircase . [She]244-bessie would never see [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow any more , but [she]244-bessie had at least done harm to [the man who had come between [her]244-bessie and [her]244-bessie desire and who used to make fun of [her]244-bessie]1450-the man who had come between her and her desire and who used to make fun of her . Then [the little privateer]1451-the little privateer sailed across [the Thames]41-the thames , to be swallowed up in [the gray wilderness of [South - the - Water]105-south - the - water]1452-the gray wilderness of south - the - water .

[Dick]147-dick slept till late in the evening , when [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow dragged [him]147-dick off to bed . [His]147-dick eyes were as bright as [his]147-dick voice was hoarse . ' Let 's have another look at the picture , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said , insistently as [a child]2344-a child .

' [You]147-dick - go - to - bed , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . ' [You]147-dick are n't at all well , though [you]147-dick may n't know it . [You]147-dick 're[156-torpenhow] as jumpy as a cat . '[156-torpenhow]

' [I]147-dick reform to - morrow . Good - night . '[147-dick]

As [he]147-dick repassed through [the studio]712-the studio , [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow lifted the cloth above the picture , and almost betrayed [himself]156-torpenhow by outcries : ' Wiped out ! - scraped out and turped out ! [Dick]147-dick could not sleep that night , partly for pure joy , and partly because the well - known Catherine - wheels inside [his]147-dick eyes had given place to crackling volcanoes of many - coloured fire . ' Spout away , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said aloud .

' [I]147-dick 've done [my]147-dick work , and now [you]147-dick can do what [you]147-dick please . '[147-dick] [He]147-dick lay still , staring at the ceiling , the long - pent - up delirium of drink in [his]147-dick veins , [his]147-dick brain on fire with racing thoughts that would not stay to be considered , and [his]147-dick hands crisped and dry . [He]147-dick had just discovered that [he]147-dick was painting the face of the Melancolia on a revolving dome ribbed with millions of lights , and that all [his]147-dick wondrous thoughts stood embodied hundreds of feet below [his]147-dick tiny swinging plank , shouting together in [his]147-dick honour , when something cracked inside [his]147-dick temples like an overstrained bowstring , the glittering dome broke inward , and [he]147-dick was alone in the thick night .

' [I]156-torpenhow 'll go to sleep . [The room]397-the room 's very dark . Let 's light a lamp and see how the Melancolia looks . There ought to have been a moon . '[156-torpenhow]

It was then that [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow heard [his]156-torpenhow name called by a voice that [he]156-torpenhow did not know , - in the rattling accents of deadly fear .

' [He]147-dick 's looked at the picture , '[156-torpenhow] was [his]156-torpenhow first thought , as [he]156-torpenhow hurried into [the bedroom]1455-the bedroom and found [Dick]147-dick sitting up and beating the air with [his]147-dick hands .

' [Torp]167-torp ! [Torp]167-torp ! where are [you]167-torp ? For pity 's sake , come to [me]147-dick ! '[147-dick]

' What 's the matter ? '[0-i]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow held the candle within a foot of [Dick]147-dick 's eyes , but there was no light in those eyes . [He]156-torpenhow lit the gas , and [Dick]147-dick heard the flame catch . ' Do n't leave [me]147-dick . [You]147-dick would n't leave [me]147-dick alone now , would [you]147-dick ? [I]147-dick ca n't see . D'you understand ? It 's black , - quite black , - and [I]147-dick feel as if [I]147-dick was falling through it all . '[147-dick]

'[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick knit [his]147-dick brows and stared desperately in front of [him]147-dick . The night air was chilling [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's toes .

' Can [you]147-dick stay like that a minute ? '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said . ' [I]147-dick 'll get [my]147-dick dressing - gown and some slippers . '[147-dick]

In the gray dawn [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow heard [Dick]147-dick talking to [himself]147-dick . ' Oh ! '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . ' This happened before . That night on [the river]411-the river . '[156-torpenhow]

The babble continued . It all bore upon [Maisie]146-maisie . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow listened attentively , and learned every detail of [Dick]147-dick 's life that had been hidden from [him]147-dick . ' [Torp]167-torp , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , from the bed , ' go out for a walk . [You]167-torp 've been here too long . [I]147-dick 'll get up . Hi ! This is annoying . [I]147-dick ca n't dress [myself]147-dick . Oh , it 's too absurd ! '[147-dick]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow helped [him]147-dick into [his]147-dick clothes and led [him]147-dick to the big chair in [the studio]712-the studio . [He]147-dick sat quietly waiting under strained nerves for the darkness to lift . It did not lift that day , nor the next . [Dick]147-dick adventured on a voyage round the walls . [He]147-dick hit [his]147-dick shins against the stove , and this suggested to [him]147-dick that it would be better to crawl on all fours , one hand in front of [him]147-dick . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow found [him]147-dick on the floor .

' [I]156-torpenhow 'm[156-torpenhow] trying to get the geography of [my]0-i new possessions , ' said [he]156-torpenhow . '[156-torpenhow] D'you remember [that nigger [you]156-torpenhow gouged in [the square]524-the square]1471-that nigger you gouged in the square ? Pity [you]156-torpenhow did n't keep the odd eye . It would have been useful . Any letters for [me]0-i ? Give [me]0-i all the ones in fat gray envelopes with a sort of crown thing outside . They 're of no importance . '[156-torpenhow]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow gave [him]147-dick a letter with a black M. on the envelope flap . [Dick]147-dick put it into [his]147-dick pocket . There was nothing in it that [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow might not have read , but it belonged to [himself]156-torpenhow and to [Maisie]146-maisie , who would never belong to [him]156-torpenhow .

' When [she]146-maisie finds that [I]147-dick do n't write , [she]146-maisie 'll stop writing . It 's better so . [I]147-dick could n't be any use to [her]146-maisie now , '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick argued , and [the tempter]1473-the tempter suggested that [he]147-dick should make known [his]147-dick condition . Every nerve in [him]147-dick revolted . ' [I]1473-the tempter have fallen low enough already . [I]1473-the tempter 'm[1473-the tempter] not going to beg for pity . Besides , it would be cruel to [her]146-maisie . ' [He]147-dick strove to put [Maisie]146-maisie out of [his]147-dick thoughts ; but [the blind]3049-the blind have many opportunities for thinking , and as the tides of [his]147-dick strength came back to [him]147-dick in the long employless days of dead darkness , [Dick]147-dick 's soul was troubled to the core . Another letter , and another , came from [Maisie]146-maisie . Then there was silence , and [Dick]147-dick sat by the window , the pulse of summer in the air , and pictured [her]146-maisie being won by [another man]2530-another man , stronger than [himself]147-dick . [His]147-dick imagination , the keener for the dark background it worked against , spared [him]147-dick no single detail that might send [him]147-dick raging up and down [the studio]712-the studio , to stumble over the stove that seemed to be in four places at once . Worst of all , tobacco would not taste in the darkness . The arrogance of [the man]493-the man had disappeared , and in its place were settled despair that [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow knew , and blind passion that [Dick]147-dick confided to [his]147-dick pillow at night . The intervals between the paroxysms were filled with intolerable waiting and the weight of intolerable darkness .[156-torpenhow]

' Come out into [the Park]812-the park , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . ' [You]147-dick have n't stirred out since the beginning of things . '[156-torpenhow]

' What 's the use ? There 's no movement in the dark ; and , besides , '[156-torpenhow] - [he]156-torpenhow paused irresolutely at the head of the stairs , - ' something will run over [me]156-torpenhow . '[156-torpenhow]

' Not if [I]156-torpenhow 'm[156-torpenhow] with [you]156-torpenhow . Proceed gingerly . '[156-torpenhow]

The roar of [the streets]659-the streets filled [Dick]147-dick with nervous terror , and [he]147-dick clung to [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's arm . ' Fancy having to feel for a gutter with [your]147-dick foot ! '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said petulantly , as [he]147-dick turned into [the Park]812-the park . ' Let 's curse [God]161-god and die . '[147-dick]

' [Sentries]3054-sentries are forbidden to pay unauthorised compliments . By [Jove]184-jove , there are [the Guards]3055-the guards ! '[156-torpenhow]

[Dick]147-dick 's figure straightened . ' Let 's get near 'em[147-dick] . Let 's go in and look . Let 's get on the grass and run . [I]0-i can smell the trees . '[0-i]

' Mind the low railing . That 's all right ! '[156-torpenhow] [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow kicked out a tuft of grass with [his]156-torpenhow heel . ' Smell that , '[156-torpenhow] [he]156-torpenhow said . ' Is n't it good ? '[156-torpenhow] [Dick]147-dick sniffed luxuriously . ' Now pick up [your]147-dick feet and run . '[147-dick] [They]1476-they approached as near to the regiment as was possible . The clank of bayonets being unfixed made [Dick]147-dick 's nostrils quiver .

' Let 's get nearer . [They]1477-they 're[1477-they] in column , are n't [they]1477-they ? '[1477-they]

' Yes . How did [you]147-dick know ? '[147-dick]

' Felt it . Oh , [[my]147-dick men]3056-my men ! - [[my]147-dick beautiful men]3057-my beautiful men ! '[147-dick] [He]147-dick edged forward as though [he]147-dick could see . ' [I]147-dick could draw [those chaps]3058-those chaps once . Who 'll draw ['em]3058-those chaps[147-dick] now ? '[147-dick]

' [They]3058-those chaps 'll move off in a minute . Do n't jump when the band begins . '[147-dick]

' Huh ! [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] not [a new charger]1478-a new charger . It 's the silences that hurt . Nearer , [Torp]167-torp ! - nearer ! Oh , [[my]0-i God]2254-my god , what would n't [I]0-i give to see ['em]3058-those chaps for a minute ! - one half - minute ! '[147-dick]

[He]147-dick could hear the armed life almost within reach of [him]147-dick , could hear the slings tighten across [the bandsman]1480-the bandsman 's chest as [he]147-dick heaved the big drum from the ground .

' Sticks crossed above [his]147-dick head , '[156-torpenhow] whispered [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

' [I]156-torpenhow know . [I]156-torpenhow know ! Who should know if [I]156-torpenhow do n't ? H'sh ! '[156-torpenhow]

The drum - sticks fell with a boom , and [the men]528-the men swung forward to the crash of [the band]1482-the band . [Dick]147-dick felt the wind of the massed movement in [his]147-dick face , heard the maddening tramp of feet and the friction of the pouches on the belts . The big drum pounded out the tune . It was a music - hall refrain that made a perfect quickstep -

[He]147-dick must be [a man of decent height]1483-a man of decent height , [He]147-dick must be [a man of weight]1484-a man of weight , [He]147-dick must come [home]2172-home on a Saturday night In a thoroughly sober state ; [He]147-dick must know how to love [me]0-i , And [he]147-dick must know how to kiss ; And if [he]147-dick 's enough to keep [us]1486-us both [I]0-i ca n't refuse [him]147-dick bliss . ' What 's the matter ? '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , as [he]156-torpenhow saw [Dick]147-dick 's head fall when [the last of [the regiment]1488-the regiment]1487-the last of the regiment had departed .

' Nothing . [I]156-torpenhow feel a little bit out of the running , - that 's all . [Torp]167-torp , take [me]156-torpenhow back . Why did [you]167-torp bring [me]156-torpenhow out ? '[156-torpenhow]

CHAPTER XII

There were [three friends that buried the fourth]1489-three friends that buried the fourth , The mould in [his]147-dick mouth and the dust in [his]147-dick eyes And [they]1489-three friends that buried the fourth went south and east , and north , - [The strong man]1490-the strong man fights , but [the sick man]1491-the sick man dies .

There were [three friends that spoke of the dead]1492-three friends that spoke of the dead , - [The strong man]1490-the strong man fights , but [the sick man]1491-the sick man dies . - ' And would [he]147-dick were with [us]1489-three friends that buried the fourth now , '[1489-three friends that buried the fourth] [they]1489-three friends that buried the fourth said , ' The sun in [our]1489-three friends that buried the fourth face and the wind in [our]1489-three friends that buried the fourth eyes . '[1489-three friends that buried the fourth]

- [Ballad]261-ballad . [THE NILGHAI]2383-the nilghai was angry with [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . [Dick]147-dick had been sent to bed , - [blind men]1496-blind men are ever under the orders of [those who can see]1497-those who can see , - and since [he]147-dick had returned from [the Park]107-the park had fluently sworn at [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow because [he]147-dick was alive , and all [the world]327-the world because it was alive and could see , while [he]147-dick , [Dick]147-dick , was dead in the death of the blind , who , at the best , are only burdens upon [[their]1496-blind men associates]1499-their associates . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow had said something about a [Mrs. Gummidge]262-mrs. gummidge , and [Dick]147-dick had retired in a black fury to handle and re - handle three unopened letters from [Maisie]146-maisie .

[The Nilghai , fat , burly , and aggressive]1500-the nilghai , fat , burly , and aggressive , was in [[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's rooms]1501-torpenhow 's rooms .

Behind [him]1500-the nilghai , fat , burly , and aggressive sat [the Keneu]183-the keneu , [the Great War Eagle]1502-the great war eagle , and between [them]1503-them lay a large map embellished with black - and - white - headed pins .

' [I]177-the nilghai was wrong about [the Balkans]48-the balkans , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai . ' But [I]177-the nilghai 'm[177-the nilghai] not wrong about this business . The whole of [our]1504-our work in [the Southern Soudan]34-the southern soudan must be done over again . [The public]692-the public does n't care , of course , but [the government]1506-the government does , and [they]1506-the government are making [their]1506-the government arrangements quietly . [You]1507-you know that as well as [I]0-i do . '[1507-you]

' [I]156-torpenhow remember how [the people]3059-the people cursed [us]1504-our when [[our]1504-our troops]618-our troops withdrew from [Omdurman]108-omdurman . It was bound to crop up sooner or later . But [I]156-torpenhow ca n't go , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . [He]156-torpenhow pointed through the open door ; it was a hot night . ' Can [you]1507-you blame [me]156-torpenhow ? '[156-torpenhow]

[The Keneu]183-the keneu purred above [his]183-the keneu pipe like a large and very happy cat - ' Do n't blame [you]1507-you in the least . It 's uncommonly good of [you]1507-you , and all the rest of it , but [every man]1221-every man - even [you]1507-you , [Torp]167-torp - must consider [his]1221-every man work . [I]183-the keneu know it sounds brutal , but [Dick]147-dick 's out of the race , - down , - [gastados]263-gastados expended , finished , done for . [He]147-dick has a little money of [his]147-dick own . [He]147-dick wo n't starve , and [you]1507-you ca n't pull out of [your]1507-you slide for [his]147-dick sake . Think of [your]1507-you own reputation . '[183-the keneu]

' [Dick]147-dick 's was five times bigger than [mine]183-the keneu and [yours]1507-you put together . '[183-the keneu]

' That was because [he]147-dick signed [his]147-dick name to everything [he]147-dick did . It 's all ended now . [You]1507-you must hold [yourself]1507-you in readiness to move out . [You]1507-you can command [your]1507-you own prices , and [you]1507-you do better work than [any three of [us]3063-us]3062-any three of us . '[183-the keneu]

' Do n't tell [me]183-the keneu how tempting it is . [I]183-the keneu 'll stay here to look after [Dick]147-dick for a while . [He]147-dick 's as cheerful as a bear with a sore head , but [I]183-the keneu think [he]147-dick likes to have [me]183-the keneu near [him]147-dick . '[183-the keneu]

[The Nilghai]177-the nilghai said something uncomplimentary about [soft - headed fools who throw away [their]1508-soft - headed fools who throw away their careers for other fools careers for [other fools]1509-other fools]1508-soft - headed fools who throw away their careers for other fools . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow flushed angrily . The constant strain of attendance on [Dick]147-dick had worn [his]156-torpenhow nerves thin .

' There remains a third fate , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu , thoughtfully . ' Consider this , and be not larger fools than necessary . [Dick]147-dick is - or rather was - [an able - bodied man of moderate attractions and a certain amount of audacity]3064-an able - bodied man of moderate attractions and a certain amount of audacity . '[183-the keneu]

' Oho ! '[1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at] said [the Nilghai , who remembered an affair at]1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at [Cairo]16-cairo . ' [I]1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at begin to see , - [Torp]167-torp , [I]1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at 'm[1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at] sorry . '[1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow nodded forgiveness : ' [You]1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at were more sorry when [he]147-dick cut [you]1510-the nilghai , who remembered an affair at out , though . - Go on , [Keneu]183-the keneu . '[156-torpenhow]

' [I]183-the keneu 've often thought , when [I]183-the keneu 've seen [men]430-men die out in [the desert]416-the desert , that if the news could be sent through [the world]327-the world , and the means of transport were quick enough , there would be [one woman]2244-one woman at least at [each man]1061-each man 's bedside . '[183-the keneu]

' There would be some mighty quaint revelations . Let [us]3070-us be grateful things are as they are , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' Let [us]3070-us rather reverently consider whether [Torp]167-torp 's three - cornered ministrations are exactly what [Dick]147-dick needs just now . - What do [you]167-torp think [yourself]167-torp , [Torp]167-torp ? '[183-the keneu]

' [I]183-the keneu know [they]3071-they are n't . But what can [I]183-the keneu do ? '[183-the keneu]

' Lay the matter before the board . [We]3070-us are [all [Dick]147-dick 's friends]3072-all dick 's friends here . [You]167-torp 've been most in [his]147-dick life . '[183-the keneu]

' But [I]183-the keneu picked it up when [he]147-dick was off [his]147-dick head . '[183-the keneu]

' The greater chance of its being true . [I]183-the keneu thought [we]3070-us should arrive . Who is [she]3073-her ? '[183-the keneu]

Then [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow told a tale in plain words , as [a special correspondent who knows how to make a verbal precis should tell it]1511-a special correspondent who knows how to make a verbal precis should tell it . [The men]528-the men listened without interruption .

' Is it possible that [a man]308-a man can come back across the years to [his]308-a man calf - love ? '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu . ' Is it possible ? '[183-the keneu]

' [I]183-the keneu give the facts . [He]147-dick says nothing about it now , but [he]147-dick sits fumbling three letters from [her]3073-her when [he]147-dick thinks [I]183-the keneu 'm[183-the keneu] not looking . What am [I]0-i to do ? '[183-the keneu]

' Speak to [him]147-dick , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' Oh yes ! Write to [her]3073-her , - [I]177-the nilghai do n't know [her]3073-her full name , remember , - and ask [her]3073-her to accept [him]147-dick out of pity . [I]177-the nilghai believe [you]177-the nilghai once told [Dick]147-dick [you]177-the nilghai were sorry for [him]147-dick , [Nilghai]177-the nilghai . [You]177-the nilghai remember what happened , eh ? Go into [the bedroom]1455-the bedroom and suggest full confession and an appeal to [this Maisie girl]3076-this maisie girl , whoever [she]3076-this maisie girl is . [I]177-the nilghai honestly believe [he]147-dick 'd try to kill [you]177-the nilghai ; and the blindness has made [him]147-dick rather muscular . '[177-the nilghai]

' [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's course is perfectly clear , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu . ' [He]156-torpenhow will go to [Vitry - sur - Marne]52-vitry - sur - marne , which is on [the Bezieres - Landes Railway]109-the bezieres - landes railway , - single track from [Tourgas]110-tourgas . [The Prussians]264-the prussians shelled [it]3077-it out in '[183-the keneu] 70 because there was a poplar on the top of a hill eighteen hundred yards from [the church]1513-the church spire There 's a squadron of [cavalry]1234-cavalry quartered there , - or ought to be . Where this studio [Torp]167-torp spoke about may be [I]0-i can not tell . That is [Torp]167-torp 's business . [I]0-i have given [him]167-torp [his]167-torp route . [He]167-torp will dispassionately explain the situation to [the girl]345-the girl , and [she]345-the girl will come back to [Dick]147-dick , - the more especially because , to use [Dick]147-dick 's words , " there is nothing but [her]345-the girl damned obstinacy to keep them apart . " '[345-the girl]

' And [they]3078-they have four hundred and twenty pounds a year between 'em[147-dick] .

[Dick]147-dick never lost [his]147-dick head for figures , even in [his]147-dick delirium . [You]1516-you have n't the shadow of an excuse for not going , ' said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .[1516-you]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow looked very uncomfortable . ' But it 's absurd and impossible . [I]156-torpenhow ca n't drag [her]345-the girl back by the hair . '[156-torpenhow]

' [[Our]3079-our business]3080-our business - the business for which [we]3079-our draw [our]3079-our money - is to do absurd and impossible things , - generally with no reason whatever except to amuse [the public]692-the public . Here [we]3079-our have a reason . The rest does n't matter . [I]156-torpenhow shall share [these rooms]707-these rooms with [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai till [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow returns . There will be a batch of unbridled '[156-torpenhow] specials " coming to [town]754-town in a little while , and these will serve as [[their]1518-their headquarters]1519-their headquarters . Another reason for sending [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow away . Thus [Providence]151-providence helps [those who help [others]790-others]1520-those who help others , and ' - here [the Keneu]3004-the keneu dropped [his]3004-the keneu measured speech - '[1522-i] [we]1522-i ca n't have [you]1523-you tied by the leg to [Dick]147-dick when the trouble begins . It 's [your]1523-you only chance of getting away ; and [Dick]147-dick will be grateful . '[147-dick]

' [He]147-dick will , - worse luck ! [I]1522-i can but go and try . [I]1522-i ca n't conceive [a woman in [her]3084-a woman in her senses senses]3084-a woman in her senses refusing [Dick]147-dick . '[1522-i]

' Talk that out with [the girl]345-the girl . [I]147-dick have seen [you]1523-you wheedle [an angry Mahdieh woman]3086-an angry mahdieh woman into giving [you]1523-you dates . '[147-dick]

' [Dick]147-dick , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , next morning , ' can [I]156-torpenhow do anything for [you]147-dick ? '[156-torpenhow]
