' Nothing [I]147-dick could go for to fetch for to carry for to bring ? '[147-dick]

' No . Take those infernal creaking boots of yours away . '[156-torpenhow]

' [Poor chap]3044-poor chap ! '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow to [himself]156-torpenhow . ' [I]156-torpenhow must have been sitting on [his]3044-poor chap nerves lately . [He]3044-poor chap wants a lighter step . '[156-torpenhow] Then , aloud , ' Very well . Since [you]147-dick 're[156-torpenhow] so independent , [I]0-i 'm going off for four or five days . Say good - bye at least . [The housekeeper]3088-the housekeeper will look after [you]147-dick , and [Keneu]183-the keneu has [[my]156-torpenhow rooms]2692-my rooms . '[156-torpenhow]

[Dick]147-dick 's face fell . ' [You]147-dick wo n't be longer than a week at the outside ? [I]147-dick know [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] touched in the temper , but [I]0-i ca n't get on without [you]147-dick . '[0-i]

' Ca n't [you]147-dick ? [You]147-dick 'll have to do without [me]156-torpenhow in a little time , and [you]147-dick 'll be glad [I]156-torpenhow 'm[156-torpenhow] gone . '[156-torpenhow]

[Dick]147-dick felt [his]147-dick way back to the big chair , and wondered what these things might mean . [He]147-dick did not wish to be tended by [the housekeeper]3088-the housekeeper , and yet [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's constant tenderness jarred on [him]147-dick . [He]147-dick did not exactly know what [he]147-dick wanted . The darkness would not lift , and [Maisie]146-maisie 's unopened letters felt worn and old from much handling . [He]147-dick could never read them for [himself]147-dick as long as life endured ; but [Maisie]146-maisie might have sent [him]147-dick some fresh ones to play with . [The Nilghai]177-the nilghai entered with a gift , - a piece of red modelling - wax . [He]177-the nilghai fancied that [Dick]147-dick might find interest in using [his]147-dick hands . [Dick]147-dick poked and patted the stuff for a few minutes , and , ' Is it like anything in [the world]327-the world ? '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said drearily . ' Take it away . [I]147-dick may get the touch of the blind in fifty years . Do [you]147-dick know where [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow has gone ? '[147-dick]

[The Nilghai]177-the nilghai knew nothing . ' [We]1527-we 're[177-the nilghai] staying in [[his]1525-his rooms]1526-his rooms till [he]1525-his comes back . Can [we]1527-we do anything for [you]147-dick ? '[177-the nilghai]

' [I]177-the nilghai 'd like to be left alone , please . Do n't think [I]177-the nilghai 'm[177-the nilghai] ungrateful ; but [I]0-i 'm best alone . '[177-the nilghai]

[The Nilghai]177-the nilghai chuckled , and [Dick]147-dick resumed [his]147-dick drowsy brooding and sullen rebellion against fate . [He]147-dick had long since ceased to think about the work [he]147-dick had done in the old days , and the desire to do more work had departed from [him]147-dick . [He]147-dick was exceedingly sorry for [himself]147-dick , and the completeness of [his]147-dick tender grief soothed [him]147-dick . But [his]147-dick soul and [his]147-dick body cried for [Maisie]146-maisie - [Maisie]146-maisie who would understand . [His]147-dick mind pointed out that [Maisie]146-maisie , having [her]146-maisie own work to do , would not care . [His]147-dick experience had taught [him]147-dick that when money was exhausted [women]775-women went away , and that when [a man]308-a man was knocked out of the race [the others]858-the others trampled on [him]308-a man . ' Then at the least , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , in reply , ' [she]146-maisie could use [me]147-dick as [I]147-dick used [Binat]162-madame , - for some sort of a study . [I]147-dick would n't ask more than to be near [her]146-maisie again , even though [I]147-dick knew that [another man]2530-another man was making love to [her]146-maisie . Ugh ! what a dog [I]147-dick am ! '[147-dick]

[A voice on the staircase]1531-a voice on the staircase began to sing joyfully -

' When [we]3092-our go - go - go away from here , [[Our]3092-our creditors]3093-our creditors will weep and [they]3093-our creditors will wail , [Our]3092-our absence much regretting when [they]3093-our creditors find that [they]3093-our creditors 've been getting Out of [England]18-england by next Tuesday 's Indian mail . '[1531-a voice on the staircase]

Following the trampling of feet , slamming of [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's door , and the sound of voices in strenuous debate , [some one]1532-some one squeaked , ' And see , [[you]147-dick good fellows]3094-you good fellows , [I]1532-some one have found a new water - bottle - firs'-class patent - eh , how [you]147-dick say ? Open [himself]1532-some one inside out . '[1532-some one]

[Dick]147-dick sprang to [his]147-dick feet . [He]147-dick knew the voice well . ' That 's [Cassavetti]176-cassavetti , come back from [the Continent]111-the continent . Now [I]147-dick know why [Torp]167-torp went away . There 's a row somewhere , and - [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] out of it ! '[147-dick]

[The Nilghai]177-the nilghai commanded silence in vain . ' That 's for [my]147-dick sake , '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick said bitterly . ' The birds are getting ready to fly , and [they]3095-they would n't tell [me]147-dick . [I]147-dick can hear [Morten - Sutherland]265-morten - sutherland and [Mackaye]266-mackaye . [Half the War Correspondents in [London]33-london]3096-half the war correspondents in london are there ; - and [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] out of it . '[147-dick]

[He]147-dick stumbled across [the landing]697-the landing and plunged into [[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's room]702-torpenhow 's room . [He]147-dick could feel that [it]702-torpenhow 's room was full of [men]430-men . ' Where 's the trouble ? '[147-dick] said [he]147-dick . ' In [the Balkans]48-the balkans at last ? Why did n't [some one]1532-some one tell [me]147-dick ? '[147-dick]

' [We]3098-we thought [you]147-dick would n't be interested , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai , shamefacedly .

' It 's in [the Soudan]45-the soudan , as usual . '[177-the nilghai]

' [You]147-dick lucky dogs ! Let [me]177-the nilghai sit here while [you]147-dick talk . [I]177-the nilghai sha n't be a skeleton at the feast . - [Cassavetti]176-cassavetti , where are [you]147-dick ? [Your]147-dick English is as bad as ever . '[177-the nilghai]

[Dick]147-dick was led into a chair . [He]147-dick heard the rustle of the maps , and the talk swept forward , carrying [him]147-dick with it . [Everybody]2627-everybody spoke at once , discussing press censorships , railway - routes , transport , water - supply , the capacities of [generals]1537-generals , - these in language that would have horrified [a trusting public]1538-a trusting public , - ranging , asserting , denouncing , and laughing at the top of [their]2627-everybody voices . There was the glorious certainty of war in [the Soudan]45-the soudan at any moment . [The Nilghai]177-the nilghai said so , and it was well to be in readiness . [The Keneu]183-the keneu had telegraphed to [Cairo]16-cairo for horses ; [Cassavetti]176-cassavetti had stolen a perfectly inaccurate list of [troops that would be ordered forward]1539-troops that would be ordered forward , and was reading it out amid profane interruptions , and [the Keneu]3004-the keneu introduced to [[Dick]147-dick some man unknown who would be employed as [war artist]1542-war artist by [the Central Southern Syndicate]112-the central southern syndicate]1541-dick some man unknown who would be employed as war artist by the central southern syndicate . ' It 's [his]1541-dick some man unknown who would be employed as war artist by the central southern syndicate first outing , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu . ' Give [him]1541-dick some man unknown who would be employed as war artist by the central southern syndicate some tips - about riding camels . '[183-the keneu]

' Oh , those camels ! '[176-cassavetti] groaned [Cassavetti]176-cassavetti . ' [I]176-cassavetti shall learn to ride [him]1541-dick some man unknown who would be employed as war artist by the central southern syndicate again , and now [I]176-cassavetti am so much all soft ! Listen , [[you]147-dick good fellows]3094-you good fellows . [I]176-cassavetti know [your]147-dick military arrangement very well . There will go [the Royal Argalshire Sutherlanders]3100-the royal argalshire sutherlanders . So it was read to [me]176-cassavetti upon best authority . '[176-cassavetti]

A roar of laughter interrupted [him]147-dick .

' Sit down , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai . ' The lists are n't even made out in [the War Office]1149-the war office . '[177-the nilghai]

' Will there be any force at [Suakin]13-suakin ? '[183-the keneu] said a voice .

Then the outcries redoubled , and grew mixed , thus : ' How many [Egyptian troops]3102-egyptian troops will [they]3102-egyptian troops use ? - God help [the Fellaheen]267-the fellaheen ! - There 's [a railway in [Plumstead]113-plumstead marshes]3103-a railway in plumstead marshes doing duty as [a fives - court]3104-a fives - court . - [We]3105-we shall have [the Suakin - Berber]114-the suakin - berber line built at last . - [Canadian voyageurs]3106-canadian voyageurs are too careful . Give [me]1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace a half - drunk Krooman in [a whale - boat]3107-a whale - boat . - [Who commands [the Desert column]3109-the desert column]3108-who commands the desert column ? - No , [they]3102-egyptian troops never blew up [the big rock in [the Ghineh bend]115-the ghineh bend]3110-the big rock in the ghineh bend . [We]3105-we shall have to be hauled up , as usual . - [Somebody]575-somebody tell [me]1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace if there 's [an Indian contingent]3112-an indian contingent , or [I]1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace 'll break [everybody]2627-everybody 's head . - Do n't tear the map in two . - It 's a war of occupation , [I]1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace tell [you]3114-you , to connect with [the African companies in [the South]116-the south]3115-the african companies in the south . - There 's Guinea - worm in [most of the wells on that route]3116-most of the wells on that route . '[1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace] Then [the Nilghai , despairing of peace]1543-the nilghai , despairing of peace , bellowed like a fog - horn and beat upon the table with both hands .

' But what becomes of [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , in the silence that followed .

' [Torp]167-torp 's in abeyance just now . [He]167-torp 's off love - making somewhere , [I]177-the nilghai suppose , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' [He]167-torp said [he]167-torp was going to stay at [home]2172-home , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu .

' Is [he]1545-he ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , with an oath . ' [He]1545-he wo n't . [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] not much good now , but if [you]1544-you and [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai hold [him]1545-he down [I]0-i 'll engage to trample on [him]1545-he till [he]1545-he sees reason . [He]1545-he 'll stay behind , indeed ! [He]1545-he 's the best of [you]1544-you all . There 'll be some tough work by [Omdurman]108-omdurman . [We]1546-we shall come [there]2480-there to stay , this time .

But [I]0-i forgot . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i were going with [you]1544-you . '[0-i]

' So do [we]1546-we all , [Dickie]175-dickie , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu .

' And [I]1548-the new artist of the central southern syndicate most of all , '[1548-the new artist of the central southern syndicate] said [the new artist of [the Central Southern Syndicate]112-the central southern syndicate]1548-the new artist of the central southern syndicate .

' Could [you]1544-you tell [me]0-i - - '[0-i]

' [I]147-dick 'll give [you]147-dick one piece of advice , '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick answered , moving towards the door . ' If [you]147-dick happen to be cut over the head in a scrimmage , do n't guard .[147-dick]

Tell [the man]493-the man to go on cutting . [You]1544-you 'll find it cheapest in the end . Thanks for letting [me]0-i look in . '[183-the keneu]

' There 's grit in [Dick]147-dick , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai , an hour later , when [the room]397-the room was emptied of all save [the Keneu]183-the keneu .

' It was the sacred call of the war - trumpet . Did [you]147-dick notice how [he]183-the keneu answered to it ? [Poor fellow]3118-poor fellow ! Let 's look at [him]183-the keneu , '[183-the keneu] said [the Keneu]183-the keneu .

The excitement of the talk had died away . [Dick]147-dick was sitting by [the studio]712-the studio table , with [his]147-dick head on [his]147-dick arms , when [the men]528-the men came in . [He]147-dick did not change [his]147-dick position .

' It hurts , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick moaned . ' [God]161-god forgive [me]147-dick , but it hurts cruelly ; and yet , y'know , [the world]327-the world has a knack of spinning round all by itself . Shall [I]147-dick see [Torp]167-torp before [he]167-torp goes ? '[147-dick]

' Oh , yes . [You]147-dick 'll see [him]167-torp , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

CHAPTER XIII

The sun went down an hour ago , [I]0-i wonder if [I]0-i face towards [home]2172-home ; If [I]0-i lost [my]0-i way in the light of day How shall [I]0-i find it now night is come ?

- [Old Song]269-old song . ' [MAISIE]146-maisie , come to bed . '[269-old song]

' It 's so hot [I]146-maisie ca n't sleep . Do n't worry . '[146-maisie]

[Maisie]146-maisie put [her]146-maisie elbows on the window - sill and looked at the moonlight on [the straight , poplar - flanked road]1554-the straight , poplar - flanked road . Summer had come upon [Vitry - sur - Marne]52-vitry - sur - marne and parched it to the bone . The grass was dry - burnt in [the meadows]1555-the meadows , the clay by [the bank of [the river]411-the river]1556-the bank of the river was caked to brick , the roadside flowers were long since dead , and the roses in [the garden]1558-the garden hung withered on their stalks . The heat in [the little low bedroom under the eaves]1559-the little low bedroom under the eaves was almost intolerable . The very moonlight on the wall of [[Kami]174-kami 's studio]1560-kami 's studio across [the road]461-the road seemed to make the night hotter , and the shadow of the big bell - handle by the closed gate cast a bar of inky black that caught [Maisie]146-maisie 's eye and annoyed [her]146-maisie .

' Horrid thing ! It should be all white , '[146-maisie] [she]146-maisie murmured . ' And the gate is n't in the middle of the wall , either . [I]146-maisie never noticed that before . '[146-maisie]

[Maisie]146-maisie was hard to please at that hour . First , the heat of the past few weeks had worn [her]146-maisie down ; secondly , [her]146-maisie work , and particularly the study of a female head intended to represent the Melancolia and not finished in time for the Salon , was unsatisfactory ; thirdly , [Kami]174-kami had said as much two days before ; fourthly , - but so completely fourthly that it was hardly worth thinking about , - [Dick]147-dick , [[her]146-maisie property]1562-her property , had not written to [her]146-maisie for more than six weeks . [She]146-maisie was angry with the heat , with [Kami]174-kami , and with [her]146-maisie work , but [she]146-maisie was exceedingly angry with [Dick]147-dick .

[She]146-maisie had written to [him]147-dick three times , - each time proposing a fresh treatment of [her]146-maisie Melancolia . [Dick]147-dick had taken no notice of these communications . [She]146-maisie had resolved to write no more . When [she]146-maisie returned to [England]18-england in the autumn - for [her]146-maisie pride 's sake [she]146-maisie could not return earlier - [she]146-maisie would speak to [him]147-dick . [She]146-maisie missed the Sunday afternoon conferences more than [she]146-maisie cared to admit . All that [Kami]174-kami said was , ' [Continuez]270-continuez , [mademoiselle]3120-mademoiselle , continuez toujours , '[147-dick] and [he]147-dick had been repeating the wearisome counsel through the hot summer , exactly like a cicada , - an old gray cicada in a black alpaca coat , white trousers , and a huge felt hat .

But [Dick]147-dick had tramped masterfully up and down [[her]146-maisie little studio north of [the cool green London park]1564-the cool green london park]1563-her little studio north of the cool green london park , and had said things ten times worse than continuez , before [he]147-dick snatched the brush out of [her]146-maisie hand and showed [her]146-maisie where the error lay . [His]147-dick last letter , [Maisie]146-maisie remembered , contained some trivial advice about not sketching in the sun or drinking water at [wayside farmhouses]1565-wayside farmhouses ; and [he]147-dick had said that not once , but three times , - as if [he]147-dick did not know that [Maisie]146-maisie could take care of [herself]146-maisie .

But what was [he]147-dick doing , that [he]147-dick could not trouble to write ? A murmur of voices in [the road]461-the road made [her]146-maisie lean from the window . [A cavalryman of the little garrison in [the town]470-the town]1567-a cavalryman of the little garrison in the town was talking to [[Kami]174-kami 's cook]1569-kami 's cook . The moonlight glittered on the scabbard of [his]147-dick sabre , which [he]147-dick was holding in [his]147-dick hand lest it should clank inopportunely . [The cook]1570-the cook 's cap cast deep shadows on [her]146-maisie face , which was close to [the conscript]1571-the conscript 's . [He]147-dick slid [his]147-dick arm round [her]146-maisie waist , and there followed the sound of a kiss .

' Faugh ! '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie , stepping back .

' What 's that ? '[2429-the red - haired girl] said [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl , who was tossing uneasily outside [her]2429-the red - haired girl bed .

' Only [a conscript]3121-a conscript kissing [the cook]1570-the cook , '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie .

' [They]3123-they 've gone away now . '[146-maisie] [She]146-maisie leaned out of the window again , and put a shawl over [her]146-maisie nightgown to guard against chills . There was a very small night - breeze abroad , and a sun - baked rose below nodded its head as [one who knew unutterable secrets]1573-one who knew unutterable secrets . Was it possible that [Dick]147-dick should turn [his]147-dick thoughts from [her]146-maisie work and [his]147-dick own and descend to the degradation of [Suzanne]271-suzanne and [the conscript]1571-the conscript ? [He]147-dick could not ! The rose nodded [its]1575-its head and one leaf therewith . It looked like a naughty little devil scratching [its]1575-its ear .

[Dick]147-dick could not , ' because , '[146-maisie] thought [Maisie]146-maisie , ' [he]147-dick is [mine]0-i , - mine , - [mine]0-i . [He]147-dick said [he]147-dick was . [I]146-maisie 'm[146-maisie] sure [I]0-i do n't care what [he]147-dick does . It will only spoil [his]147-dick work if [he]147-dick does ; and it will spoil [mine]0-i too . '[146-maisie]

The rose continued to nod in the futile way peculiar to flowers . There was no earthly reason why [Dick]147-dick should not disport [himself]147-dick as [he]147-dick chose , except that [he]147-dick was called by [Providence]151-providence , which was [Maisie]146-maisie , to assist [Maisie]146-maisie in [her]146-maisie work . And [her]146-maisie work was the preparation of pictures that went sometimes to English provincial exhibitions , as the notices in the scrap - book proved , and that were invariably rejected by [the Salon]2417-the salon when [Kami]174-kami was plagued into allowing [her]146-maisie to send them up . [Her]146-maisie work in the future , it seemed , would be the preparation of pictures on exactly similar lines which would be rejected in exactly the same way - - [The red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl threshed distressfully across the sheets . ' It 's too hot to sleep , '[146-maisie] [she]146-maisie moaned ; and the interruption jarred .

Exactly the same way . Then [she]146-maisie would divide [her]146-maisie years between [the little studio in [England]18-england]1578-the little studio in england and [[Kami]174-kami 's big studio at [Vitry - sur - Marne]52-vitry - sur - marne]1579-kami 's big studio at vitry - sur - marne . No , [she]146-maisie would go to [another master , who should force [her]146-maisie into the success that was [her]146-maisie right]1580-another master , who should force her into the success that was her right , if [patient toil and desperate endeavour]1581-patient toil and desperate endeavour gave [one]727-one a right to anything . [Dick]147-dick had told [her]146-maisie that [he]147-dick had worked ten years to understand [his]147-dick craft . [She]146-maisie had worked ten years , and ten years were nothing . [Dick]147-dick had said that ten years were nothing , - but that was in regard to [herself]146-maisie only . [He]147-dick had said - [this very man who could not find time to write]1583-this very man who could not find time to write - that [he]147-dick would wait ten years for [her]146-maisie , and that [she]146-maisie was bound to come back to [him]147-dick sooner or later . [He]147-dick had said this in the absurd letter about sunstroke and diphtheria ; and then [he]147-dick had stopped writing . [He]147-dick was wandering up and down [moonlit streets]1584-moonlit streets , kissing [cooks]1585-cooks . [She]146-maisie would like to lecture [him]147-dick now , - not in [her]146-maisie nightgown , of course , but properly dressed , severely and from a height . Yet if [he]147-dick was kissing [other girls]1586-other girls [he]147-dick certainly would not care whether [she]146-maisie lectured [him]147-dick or not . [He]147-dick would laugh at [her]146-maisie . Very good .

[She]146-maisie would go back to [[her]146-maisie studio]1587-her studio and prepare pictures that went , etc . , etc .

The mill - wheel of thought swung round slowly , that no section of it might be slurred over , and [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl tossed and turned behind [her]146-maisie .

[Maisie]146-maisie put [her]146-maisie chin in [her]146-maisie hands and decided that there could be no doubt whatever of the villainy of [Dick]147-dick . To justify [herself]146-maisie , [she]146-maisie began , unwomanly , to weigh the evidence . There was [a boy]1589-a boy , and [he]1589-a boy had said [he]1589-a boy loved [her]146-maisie . And [he]1589-a boy kissed [her]146-maisie , - kissed [her]146-maisie on the cheek , - by a yellow sea - poppy that nodded its head exactly like the maddening dry rose in [the garden]1558-the garden . Then there was an interval , and [men]430-men had told [her]146-maisie that [they]430-men loved [her]146-maisie - just when [she]146-maisie was busiest with [her]146-maisie work . Then [the boy]368-the boy came back , and at [their]1593-their very second meeting had told [her]146-maisie that [he]1589-a boy loved [her]146-maisie . Then [he]1589-a boy had - - But there was no end to the things [he]1589-a boy had done . [He]1589-a boy had given [her]146-maisie [his]1589-a boy time and [his]1589-a boy powers . [He]1589-a boy had spoken to [her]146-maisie of Art , housekeeping , technique , teacups , the abuse of pickles as a stimulant , - that was rude , - sable hair - brushes , - [he]1589-a boy had given [her]146-maisie the best in [her]146-maisie stock , - [she]146-maisie used them daily ; [he]1589-a boy had given [her]146-maisie advice that [she]146-maisie profited by , and now and again - a look . Such a look ! The look of a beaten hound waiting for the word to crawl to [[his]1589-a boy mistress]355-his mistress 's feet . In return [she]146-maisie had given [him]1589-a boy nothing whatever , except - here [she]146-maisie brushed [her]146-maisie mouth against the open - work sleeve f [her]146-maisie nightgown - the privilege of kissing [her]146-maisie once . And on the mouth , too . Disgraceful ! Was that not enough , and more than enough ? and if it was not , had [he]1589-a boy not cancelled the debt by not writing and - probably kissing [other girls]1586-other girls ? ' [Maisie]146-maisie , [you]146-maisie 'll catch a chill . Do go and lie down , '[1259-her companion] said the wearied voice of [[her]146-maisie companion]1259-her companion . ' [I]1259-her companion ca n't sleep a wink with [you]146-maisie at the window . '[1259-her companion]

[Maisie]146-maisie shrugged [her]146-maisie shoulders and did not answer . [She]146-maisie was reflecting on the meannesses of [Dick]147-dick , and on other meannesses with which [he]1589-a boy had nothing to do . The moonlight would not let [her]146-maisie sleep . It lay on the skylight of [the studio]712-the studio across [the road]461-the road in cold silver ; [she]146-maisie stared at it intently and [her]146-maisie thoughts began to slide one into the other . The shadow of the big bell - handle in the wall grew short , lengthened again , and faded out as the moon went down behind [the pasture]1599-the pasture and a hare came limping [home]2172-home across [the road]461-the road . Then the dawn - wind washed through the upland grasses , and brought coolness with it , and the cattle lowed by [the drought - shrunk river]1602-the drought - shrunk river . [Maisie]146-maisie 's head fell forward on the window - sill , and the tangle of black hair covered [her]146-maisie arms .

' [Maisie]146-maisie , wake up . [You]146-maisie 'll catch a chill . '[146-maisie]

' Yes , [dear]2419-dear ; yes , [dear]2419-dear . '[146-maisie] [She]146-maisie staggered to [her]146-maisie bed like [a wearied child]1603-a wearied child , and as [she]146-maisie buried [her]146-maisie face in the pillows [she]146-maisie muttered , ' [I]146-maisie think - [I]146-maisie think ....[146-maisie]

But [he]1604-he ought to have written . '[146-maisie]

Day brought the routine of [the studio]712-the studio , the smell of paint and turpentine , and the monotone wisdom of [Kami]174-kami , who was [a leaden artist]1606-a leaden artist , but [a golden teacher]1607-a golden teacher if [the pupil]1608-the pupil were only in sympathy with [him]174-kami . [Maisie]146-maisie was not in sympathy that day , and [she]146-maisie waited impatiently for the end of the work .

[She]146-maisie knew when it was coming ; for [Kami]174-kami would gather [his]174-kami black alpaca coat into a bunch behind [him]174-kami , and , with faded blue eyes that saw [neither pupils nor canvas]1609-neither pupils nor canvas , look back into the past to recall the history of [one Binat]1610-one binat . ' [You]1028-the students have all done not so badly , '[174-kami] [he]174-kami would say . ' But [you]1028-the students shall remember that it is not enough to have the method , and the art , and the power , nor even that which is touch , but [you]1028-the students shall have also the conviction that nails the work to the wall . Of the so many [I]174-kami taught , '[174-kami] - here [the students]1028-the students would begin to unfix drawing - pins or get [their]1028-the students tubes together , - ' the very so many that [I]174-kami have taught , the best was [Binat]162-madame . All that comes of the study and the work and the knowledge was to [him]174-kami even when [he]174-kami came . After [he]174-kami left [me]174-kami [he]174-kami should have done all that could be done with the colour , the form , and the knowledge . Only , [he]174-kami had not the conviction . So to - day [I]174-kami hear no more of [Binat]162-madame , - [the best of [[my]174-kami pupils]3127-my pupils]3126-the best of my pupils , - and that is long ago . So to - day , too , [you]3128-you will be glad to hear no more of [me]174-kami . Continuez , mesdemoiselles , and , above all , with conviction . '[174-kami]

[He]1612-he went into [the garden]1558-the garden to smoke and mourn over [the lost Binat]162-madame as [the pupils]1614-the pupils dispersed to [[their]1614-the pupils several cottages]1615-their several cottages or loitered in [the studio]712-the studio to make plans for the cool of the afternoon .

[Maisie]146-maisie looked at [her]146-maisie very unhappy Melancolia , restrained a desire to grimace before it , and was hurrying across [the road]461-the road to write a letter to [Dick]147-dick , when [she]146-maisie was aware of [a large man on a white troop - horse]1618-a large man on a white troop - horse . How [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow had managed in the course of twenty hours to find [his]156-torpenhow way to the hearts of [the cavalry officers in quarters at [Vitry - sur - Marne]52-vitry - sur - marne]1619-the cavalry officers in quarters at vitry - sur - marne , to discuss with [them]1619-the cavalry officers in quarters at vitry - sur - marne the certainty of a glorious revenge for [France]3-france , to reduce [the colonel]1620-the colonel to tears of pure affability , and to borrow the best horse in [the squadron]1621-the squadron for the journey to [[Kami]174-kami 's studio]1560-kami 's studio , is a mystery that [only special correspondents]1623-only special correspondents can unravel .

' [I]156-torpenhow beg [your]146-maisie pardon , '[156-torpenhow] said [he]156-torpenhow . ' It seems an absurd question to ask , but the fact is that [I]156-torpenhow do n't know [her]3129-her by any other name : Is there [any young lady here that is called [Maisie]146-maisie]3130-any young lady here that is called maisie ? '[156-torpenhow]

' [I]146-maisie am [Maisie]146-maisie , '[146-maisie] was the answer from the depths of a great sun - hat .

' [I]156-torpenhow ought to introduce [myself]156-torpenhow , '[156-torpenhow] [he]156-torpenhow said , as the horse capered in the blinding white dust . ' [My]156-torpenhow name is [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow . [Dick Heldar]147-dick is [[my]156-torpenhow best friend]3131-my best friend , and - and - the fact is that [he]147-dick has gone blind . '[156-torpenhow]

' Blind ! '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie , stupidly . ' [He]147-dick ca n't be blind . '[146-maisie]

' [He]147-dick has been stone - blind for nearly two months . '[156-torpenhow]

[Maisie]146-maisie lifted up [her]146-maisie face , and it was pearly white . ' No ! No ! Not blind ! [I]146-maisie wo n't have [him]147-dick blind ! '[146-maisie]

' Would [you]146-maisie care to see for [yourself]146-maisie ? '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

' Now , - at once ? '[146-maisie]

' Oh , no ! [The [Paris]44-paris train]3132-the paris train does n't go through [this place]2279-this place till to - night . There will be ample time . '[146-maisie]

' Did [Mr. Heldar]165-mr. heldar send [you]146-maisie to [me]146-maisie ? '[146-maisie]

' Certainly not . [Dick]147-dick would n't do that sort of thing . [He]147-dick 's sitting in [[his]147-dick studio]2374-his studio , turning over some letters that [he]147-dick ca n't read because [he]147-dick 's blind . '[146-maisie]

There was a sound of choking from the sun - hat . [Maisie]146-maisie bowed [her]146-maisie head and went into [the cottage]1624-the cottage , where [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl was on a sofa , complaining of a headache .

' [Dick]147-dick 's blind ! '[146-maisie] said [Maisie]146-maisie , taking [her]146-maisie breath quickly as [she]146-maisie steadied [herself]146-maisie against a chair - back . ' [[My]146-maisie Dick]3135-my dick 's blind ! '[146-maisie]

' What ? '[345-the girl] [The girl]345-the girl was on the sofa no longer .

' [A man]308-a man has come from [England]18-england to tell [me]146-maisie . [He]308-a man has n't written to [me]146-maisie for six weeks . '[146-maisie]

' Are [you]146-maisie going to [him]308-a man ? '[146-maisie]

' [I]146-maisie must think . '[146-maisie]

' Think ! [I]146-maisie should go back to [London]33-london and see [him]308-a man and [I]146-maisie should kiss [his]308-a man eyes and kiss them and kiss [them]308-a man until [they]308-a man got well again ! If [you]308-a man do n't go [I]146-maisie shall . Oh , what am [I]146-maisie talking about ? [[You]308-a man wicked little idiot]3137-you wicked little idiot ! Go to [him]308-a man at once . Go ! '[146-maisie]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's neck was blistering , but [he]156-torpenhow preserved a smile of infinite patience as [Maisie]146-maisie appeared bareheaded in the sunshine .

' [I]146-maisie am coming , '[146-maisie] said [she]146-maisie , [her]146-maisie eyes on the ground .

' [You]156-torpenhow will be at [Vitry Station]117-vitry station , then , at seven this evening . '[156-torpenhow] This was an order delivered by one who was used to being obeyed . [Maisie]146-maisie said nothing , but [she]146-maisie felt grateful that there was no chance of disputing with [this big man who took everything for granted and managed a squealing horse]1627-this big man who took everything for granted and managed a squealing horse with one hand . [She]146-maisie returned to [the red - haired girl]2429-the red - haired girl , who was weeping bitterly , and between tears , kisses , - very few of those , - menthol , packing , and an interview with [Kami]174-kami , the sultry afternoon wore away .

Thought might come afterwards . [Her]146-maisie present duty was to go to [Dick]147-dick , - Dick who owned [the wondrous friend]1629-the wondrous friend and sat in the dark playing with [her]146-maisie unopened letters .

' But what will [you]1259-her companion do , '[146-maisie] [she]146-maisie said to [[her]146-maisie companion]1259-her companion .

' [I]146-maisie ? Oh , [I]146-maisie shall stay here and - finish [your]1259-her companion Melancolia , '[146-maisie] [she]146-maisie said , smiling pitifully . ' Write to [me]146-maisie afterwards . '[146-maisie]

That night there ran a legend through [Vitry - sur - Marne]52-vitry - sur - marne of [a mad Englishman , doubtless suffering from sunstroke]1631-a mad englishman , doubtless suffering from sunstroke , who had drunk [all the officers of [the garrison under the table]1633-the garrison under the table]1632-all the officers of the garrison under the table , had borrowed a horse from the lines , and had then and there eloped , after the English custom , with [one of [those more mad English girls who drew pictures down there under the care of that good [Monsieur Kami]174-kami]1635-those more mad english girls who drew pictures down there under the care of that good monsieur kami]1634-one of those more mad english girls who drew pictures down there under the care of that good monsieur kami .

' They are very droll , '[271-suzanne] said [Suzanne]271-suzanne to [the conscript in the moonlight by the studio wall]1636-the conscript in the moonlight by the studio wall . ' [She]146-maisie walked always with those big eyes that saw nothing , and yet [she]146-maisie kisses [me]271-suzanne on both cheeks as though [she]146-maisie were [[my]271-suzanne sister]3138-my sister , and gives [me]271-suzanne - see - ten francs ! '[271-suzanne]

[The conscript]1571-the conscript levied a contribution on both gifts ; for [he]1571-the conscript prided [himself]1571-the conscript on being [a good soldier]1638-a good soldier .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow spoke very little to [Maisie]146-maisie during the journey to [Calais]118-calais ; but [he]156-torpenhow was careful to attend to all [her]146-maisie wants , to get [her]146-maisie [a compartment entirely to [herself]146-maisie]1639-a compartment entirely to herself , and to leave [her]146-maisie alone . [He]156-torpenhow was amazed of the ease with which the matter had been accomplished .

' The safest thing would be to let [her]146-maisie think things out . By [Dick]147-dick 's showing , - when [he]147-dick was off [his]147-dick head , - [she]146-maisie must have ordered [him]147-dick about very thoroughly . Wonder how [she]146-maisie likes being under orders . '[156-torpenhow]

[Maisie]146-maisie never told . [She]146-maisie sat in [the empty compartment]1640-the empty compartment often with [her]146-maisie eyes shut , that [she]146-maisie might realise the sensation of blindness . It was an order that [she]146-maisie should return to [London]33-london swiftly , and [she]146-maisie found [herself]146-maisie at last almost beginning to enjoy the situation . This was better than looking after luggage and [a red - haired friend who never took any interest in [her]146-maisie surroundings]1641-a red - haired friend who never took any interest in her surroundings . But there appeared to be a feeling in the air that [she]146-maisie , [Maisie]146-maisie , - of [all people]1642-all people , - was in disgrace . Therefore [she]146-maisie justified [her]146-maisie conduct to [herself]146-maisie with great success , till [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow came up to [her]146-maisie on [the steamer]1278-the steamer and without preface began to tell the story of [Dick]147-dick 's blindness , suppressing a few details , but dwelling at length on the miseries of delirium . [He]156-torpenhow stopped before [he]156-torpenhow reached the end , as though [he]156-torpenhow had lost interest in the subject , and went forward to smoke . [Maisie]146-maisie was furious with [him]156-torpenhow and with [herself]146-maisie .

[She]146-maisie was hurried on from [Dover]97-dover to [London]33-london almost before [she]146-maisie could ask for breakfast , and - [she]146-maisie was past any feeling of indignation now - was bidden curtly to wait in [a hall at the foot of some lead - covered stairs]1644-a hall at the foot of some lead - covered stairs while [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow went up to make inquiries . Again the knowledge that [she]146-maisie was being treated like [a naughty little girl]1645-a naughty little girl made [her]146-maisie pale cheeks flame . It was all [Dick]147-dick 's fault for being so stupid as to go blind .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow led [her]146-maisie up to a shut door , which [he]156-torpenhow opened very softly . [Dick]147-dick was sitting by the window , with [his]147-dick chin on [his]147-dick chest . There were three envelopes in [his]147-dick hand , and [he]147-dick turned them over and over . [The big man who gave orders]1646-the big man who gave orders was no longer by [her]146-maisie side , and [the studio]712-the studio door snapped behind [her]146-maisie .

[Dick]147-dick thrust the letters into [his]147-dick pocket as [he]147-dick heard the sound . ' Hullo , [Torp]167-torp ! Is that [you]167-torp ? [I]147-dick 've been so lonely . '[147-dick]

[His]147-dick voice had taken the peculiar flatness of the blind . [Maisie]146-maisie pressed [herself]146-maisie up into a corner of [the room]397-the room . [Her]146-maisie heart was beating furiously , and [she]146-maisie put one hand on [her]146-maisie breast to keep it quiet . [Dick]147-dick was staring directly at [her]146-maisie , and [she]146-maisie realised for the first time that [he]147-dick was blind .

Shutting [her]146-maisie eyes in a rail - way carriage to open them when [she]146-maisie pleased was [child]1649-child 's play . [This man]1650-this man was blind though [his]147-dick eyes were wide open .

' [Torp]167-torp , is that [you]1650-this man ? [They]3139-they said [you]1650-this man were coming . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick looked puzzled and a little irritated at the silence .

' No ; it 's only [me]147-dick , '[147-dick] was the answer , in a strained little whisper . [Maisie]146-maisie could hardly move [her]146-maisie lips .

' H'm ! '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , composedly , without moving . ' This is a new phenomenon . [Darkness]272-darkness [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] getting used to ; but [I]0-i object to hearing voices . '[0-i]

Was [he]147-dick mad , then , as well as blind , that [he]147-dick talked to [himself]147-dick ? [Maisie]146-maisie 's heart beat more wildly , and [she]146-maisie breathed in gasps . [Dick]147-dick rose and began to feel [his]147-dick way across [the room]397-the room , touching each table and chair as [he]147-dick passed . Once [he]147-dick caught [his]147-dick foot on a rug , and swore , dropping on [his]147-dick knees to feel what the obstruction might be . [Maisie]146-maisie remembered [him]147-dick walking in [the Park]812-the park as though all [the earth]2665-the earth belonged to [him]147-dick , tramping up and down [[her]146-maisie studio]1587-her studio two months ago , and flying up [the gangway of [the Channel steamer]1656-the channel steamer]1655-the gangway of the channel steamer . The beating of [her]146-maisie heart was making [her]146-maisie sick , and [Dick]147-dick was coming nearer , guided by the sound of [her]146-maisie breathing . [She]146-maisie put out a hand mechanically to ward [him]147-dick off or to draw [him]147-dick to [herself]146-maisie , [she]146-maisie did not know which . ' It 's [Maisie]146-maisie ! '[147-dick] said [he]147-dick , with a dry sob . ' What are [you]147-dick doing here ? '[147-dick]

' [I]147-dick came - [I]147-dick came - to see [you]147-dick , please . '[147-dick]

[He]0-i groped back to [his]0-i chair , [his]0-i chest labouring as [he]0-i sat down .

[Maisie]146-maisie watched [him]0-i , and the fear went out of [her]146-maisie heart , to be followed by a very bitter shame . [He]0-i had spoken a truth that had been hidden from [the girl]345-the girl through every step of the impetuous flight to [London]33-london ; for [he]0-i was , indeed , down and done for - masterful no longer but rather a little abject ; neither [an artist stronger than [she]146-maisie]1659-an artist stronger than she , nor [a man to be looked up to]1660-a man to be looked up to - only [some blind one that sat in a chair and seemed on the point of crying]1661-some blind one that sat in a chair and seemed on the point of crying . [She]146-maisie was immensely and unfeignedly sorry for [him]0-i - more sorry than [she]146-maisie had ever been for any one in [her]146-maisie life , but not sorry enough to deny [his]0-i words .

So [she]146-maisie stood still and felt ashamed and a little hurt , because [she]146-maisie had honestly intended that [her]146-maisie journey should end triumphantly ; and now [she]146-maisie was only filled with pity most startlingly distinct from love .

' Well ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , [his]147-dick face steadily turned away . ' [I]147-dick never meant to worry [you]146-maisie any more . What 's the matter ? '[147-dick]

[He]147-dick was conscious that [Maisie]146-maisie was catching [her]146-maisie breath , but was as unprepared as [herself]146-maisie for the torrent of emotion that followed . [She]146-maisie had dropped into a chair and was sobbing with [her]146-maisie face hidden in [her]146-maisie hands .

' [I]146-maisie ca n't - [I]146-maisie ca n't ! '[146-maisie] [she]146-maisie cried desperately . ' Indeed , [I]146-maisie ca n't . It is n't [my]146-maisie fault .[146-maisie]

[Dick]147-dick 's shoulders straightened again , for the words lashed like a whip .

Still the sobbing continued . It is not good to realise that [you]147-dick have failed in the hour of trial or flinched before the mere possibility of making sacrifices .

' [I]146-maisie do despise [myself]146-maisie - indeed [I]146-maisie do . But [I]146-maisie ca n't . Oh , [Dickie]175-dickie , [you]175-dickie would n't ask [me]146-maisie - would [you]175-dickie ? '[146-maisie] wailed [Maisie]146-maisie .

[Maisie]146-maisie was crying more subduedly , for the first time in [her]146-maisie life glad that [she]146-maisie had something to lean against . ' Well ? '[0-i]

The voice was fuller and more rounded , because [the man]493-the man knew [he]493-the man was speaking of [his]493-the man best work . [Maisie]146-maisie looked at the blur , and a lunatic desire to laugh caught [her]146-maisie by the throat . ' [I]146-maisie ? Oh yes - thank [you]0-i . Ha ! ha ! '[146-maisie] If [she]146-maisie did not fly at once the laughter that was worse than tears would kill [her]146-maisie . And that is the end of [Maisie]146-maisie .

For [Dick]147-dick was reserved more searching torment . ' [Hullo]273-hullo ! '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , entering [the studio]712-the studio after [Dick]147-dick had enjoyed two hours of thought . ' [I]156-torpenhow 'm[156-torpenhow] back . Are [you]156-torpenhow feeling any better ? '[156-torpenhow]

' [Torp]167-torp , [I]147-dick do n't know what to say . Come here . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick coughed huskily , wondering , indeed , what [he]147-dick should say , and how to say it temperately .

' What 's the need for saying anything ? Get up and tramp . '[156-torpenhow] [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow was perfectly satisfied .

[They]1679-they walked up and down as of custom , [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's hand on [Dick]147-dick 's shoulder , and [Dick]147-dick buried in [his]147-dick own thoughts .

' [You]156-torpenhow should n't go off [your]156-torpenhow head if [you]156-torpenhow want to keep secrets , [Dickie]175-dickie . ' Would [you]156-torpenhow have stayed with [me]1680-me , then , if - things had gone wrong ? '[1680-me] [He]1680-me put [his]1680-me question cautiously .

' [You]156-torpenhow 've tried to be [an angel]2647-an angel very successfully . '[156-torpenhow]

' [I]156-torpenhow do n't think [I]156-torpenhow will , [old man]2243-old man , if it 's all the same to [you]2243-old man . [I]156-torpenhow 'll stay quiet [here]2226-here . '[156-torpenhow]

' And meditate ? [I]308-a man do n't blame [you]2243-old man . [You]2243-old man observe a good time if ever [a man]308-a man did . '[308-a man]

That night there was a tumult on the stairs . [The correspondents]1682-the correspondents poured in from theatre , dinner , and music - hall to [[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's room]702-torpenhow 's room that [they]1682-the correspondents might discuss [their]1682-the correspondents plan of campaign in the event of military operations becoming a certainty . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , [the Keneu]183-the keneu , and [the Nilghai]2383-the nilghai had bidden [all the men [they]1682-the correspondents had worked with to the orgy]1685-all the men they had worked with to the orgy ; and [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton , [the housekeeper]3088-the housekeeper , declared that never before in [his]189-mr. beeton checkered experience had [he]189-mr. beeton seen quite such [a fancy lot of [gentlemen]1322-gentlemen]1687-a fancy lot of gentlemen . [They]1687-a fancy lot of gentlemen waked [the chambers]683-the chambers with shoutings and song ; and [the elder men]1690-the elder men were quite as bad as [the younger]1691-the younger . For the chances of war were in front of [them]1687-a fancy lot of gentlemen , and all knew what those meant .

Sitting in [[his]1692-his own room]1241-his own room a little perplexed by the noise across [the landing]697-the landing , [Dick]147-dick suddenly began to laugh to [himself]1692-his .

' When one comes to think of it the situation is intensely comic . [Maisie]146-maisie 's quite right - poor little thing . [I]1695-i did n't know [she]146-maisie could cry like that before ; but now [I]1695-i know what [Torp]167-torp thinks , [I]1695-i 'm[1695-i] sure [he]1695-i 'd be quite fool enough to stay at [home]2172-home and try to console [me]0-i - if [he]1695-i knew . Besides , it is n't nice to own that [you]1697-you 've been thrown over like a broken chair . [I]0-i must carry this business through alone - as usual . If there is n't a war , and [Torp]167-torp finds out , [I]0-i shall look foolish , that 's all . If there is a way [I]0-i must n't interfere with [another man]2530-another man 's chances . Business is business , and [I]0-i want to be alone - [I]0-i want to be alone . What a row [they]1699-they 're making ! '[575-somebody]

[Somebody]575-somebody hammered at [the studio]712-the studio door .

' Come out and frolic , [Dickie]175-dickie , '[177-the nilghai] said [the Nilghai]177-the nilghai .

' [I]575-somebody should like to , but [I]575-somebody ca n't . [I]575-somebody 'm[575-somebody] not feeling frolicsome . '[575-somebody]

' Then , [I]575-somebody 'll tell [the boys]326-the boys and [they]326-the boys 'll drag [you]175-dickie like a badger . '[575-somebody]

' Please not , [old man]2243-old man . On [my]575-somebody word , [I]575-somebody 'd sooner be left alone just now . '[575-somebody]

' Very good . Can [we]3161-we send anything in to [you]175-dickie ? [Fizz]274-fizz , for instance .[575-somebody]

[Cassavetti]176-cassavetti is beginning to sing songs of the Sunny South already . '[176-cassavetti]

For one minute [Dick]147-dick considered the proposition seriously .

' No , thanks , [I]575-somebody 've a headache already . '[575-somebody]

' [Virtuous child]3162-virtuous child . That 's the effect of emotion on [the young]322-the young . All [my]575-somebody congratulations , [Dick]147-dick . [I]575-somebody also was concerned in the conspiracy for [your]147-dick welfare . '[575-somebody]

' Go to the devil - oh , send [Binkie]180-binkie in here . '[575-somebody]

The little dog entered on elastic feet , riotous from having been made much of all the evening . [He]147-dick had helped to sing the choruses ; but scarcely inside [the studio]712-the studio [he]147-dick realised that this was no place for tail - wagging , and settled [himself]147-dick on [Dick]147-dick 's lap till it was bedtime . Then [he]147-dick went to bed with [Dick]147-dick , who counted every hour as it struck , and rose in the morning with a painfully clear head to receive [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's more formal congratulations and a particular account of the last night 's revels .

' [You]147-dick are n't looking very happy for [a newly accepted man]3164-a newly accepted man , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

' Never mind that - it 's [my]147-dick own affair , and [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] all right . Do [you]147-dick really go ? '[147-dick]

' Yes . With the old Central Southern as usual . [They]3165-they wired , and [I]147-dick accepted on better terms than before . '[147-dick]

' When do [you]147-dick start ? '[147-dick]

' The day after to - morrow - for [Brindisi]119-brindisi . '[147-dick]

' Thank [God]161-god . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick spoke from the bottom of [his]147-dick heart .

' Well , that 's not a pretty way of saying [you]147-dick 're[147-dick] glad to get rid of [me]0-i . But [men in [your]147-dick condition]1703-men in your condition are allowed to be selfish . '[147-dick]

' [I]147-dick did n't mean that . Will [you]147-dick get a hundred pounds cashed for [me]147-dick before [you]147-dick leave ? '[147-dick]

' That 's a slender amount for housekeeping , is n't it ? '[147-dick]

' Oh , it 's only for - marriage expenses . '[147-dick]

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow brought [him]147-dick the money , counted it out in fives and tens , and carefully put it away in the writing table .

' Now [I]156-torpenhow suppose [I]156-torpenhow shall have to listen to [his]147-dick ravings about [[his]147-dick girl]3166-his girl until [I]156-torpenhow go . [Heaven]178-heaven send [us]3167-us patience with [a man in love]3168-a man in love ! '[156-torpenhow] [he]156-torpenhow said to [himself]156-torpenhow .

But never a word did [Dick]147-dick say of [Maisie]146-maisie or marriage . [He]147-dick hung in the doorway of [[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's room]702-torpenhow 's room when [the latter]487-the latter was packing and asked innumerable questions about the coming campaign , till [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow began to feel annoyed .

' [You]175-dickie 're[147-dick] a secretive animal , [Dickie]175-dickie , and [you]175-dickie consume [your]175-dickie own smoke , do n't [you]175-dickie ? ' [he]147-dick said on the last evening .[175-dickie]

' [I]175-dickie - [I]175-dickie suppose so . By the way , how long do [you]175-dickie think this war will last ? '[175-dickie]

' Days , weeks , or months . [One]727-one can never tell . It may go on for years . '[175-dickie]

' [I]175-dickie wish [I]175-dickie were going . '[175-dickie]

' [Good Heavens]275-good heavens ! [You]175-dickie 're[175-dickie] the most unaccountable creature ! Has n't it occurred to [you]175-dickie that [you]175-dickie 're going to be married - thanks to [me]175-dickie ? '[175-dickie]

' Of course , yes . [I]175-dickie 'm[175-dickie] going to be married - so [I]0-i am . Going to be married .

[I]0-i 'm awfully grateful to [you]175-dickie . Have n't [I]0-i told [you]175-dickie that ? '[0-i]

' [You]175-dickie might be going to be hanged by the look of [you]175-dickie , '[156-torpenhow] said [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow .

And the next day [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow bade [him]156-torpenhow good - bye and left [him]156-torpenhow to the loneliness [he]156-torpenhow had so much desired .

CHAPTER XIV

Yet at the last , ere [[our]1706-our spearmen]1707-our spearmen had found [him]156-torpenhow , Yet at the last , [ere]1708-ere a sword - thrust could save , Yet at the last , with [[his]156-torpenhow masters]1709-his masters around [him]156-torpenhow , [[He]156-torpenhow of the Faith]1710-he of the faith spoke as [master]1711-master to [slave]1712-slave ; Yet at the last , tho ' [the Kafirs]276-the kafirs had maimed [him]156-torpenhow , Broken by bondage and wrecked by [the reiver]3170-the reiver , - Yet at the last , tho '[156-torpenhow] the darkness had claimed [him]156-torpenhow , [He]156-torpenhow called upon [Allah]196-allah and died [a believer]1713-a believer .

- [Kizzilbashi]277-kizzilbashi . ' BEG [your]189-mr. beeton pardon , [Mr. Heldar]165-mr. heldar , but - but is n't nothin' going to happen ? '[189-mr. beeton] said [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton .

' No ! '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick had just waked to another morning of blank despair and [his]147-dick temper was of the shortest .

" Tain't [my]0-i regular business , o ' course , [sir]2295-sir ; and what [I]147-dick say is , " Mind [your]1714-your own business and let [other people]2459-other people mind [theirs]2459-other people ; " but just before [Mr.[147-dick]

Torpenhow]156-torpenhow went away [he]156-torpenhow give [me]0-i to understand , like , that [you]1714-your might be moving into [a house of [your]1714-your own]1715-a house of your own , so to speak - [a sort of house with rooms [upstairs]1717-upstairs and downstairs where [you]1714-your 'd be better attended to]1716-a sort of house with rooms upstairs and downstairs where you 'd be better attended to , though [I]0-i try to act just by all [[our]1718-our tenants]1719-our tenants . Do n't [I]0-i ? '[0-i]

' Ah ! That must have been [a mad - house]3173-a mad - house . [I]189-mr. beeton sha n't trouble [you]2295-sir to take [me]189-mr. beeton [there]2480-there yet . Get [me]189-mr. beeton [my]189-mr. beeton breakfast , please , and leave [me]189-mr. beeton alone . '[189-mr. beeton]

' [I]0-i hope [I]0-i have n't done anything wrong , [sir]2295-sir , but [you]2295-sir know [I]0-i hope that as far as [a man]308-a man can [I]0-i tries to do the proper thing by all [the gentlemen in [chambers]744-chambers]3177-the gentlemen in chambers - and more particular those whose lot is hard - such as [you]2295-sir , for instance , [Mr. Heldar]165-mr. heldar . [You]2295-sir likes soft - roe bloater , do n't [you]2295-sir ? Soft - roe bloaters is scarcer than hard - roe , but what [I]0-i says is , " Never mind a little extra trouble so long as [you]2295-sir give satisfaction to [the tenants]3179-the tenants . " '[0-i]

[Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton withdrew and left [Dick]147-dick to [himself]189-mr. beeton . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow had been long away ; there was no more rioting in [the chambers]683-the chambers , and [Dick]147-dick had settled down to [his]147-dick new life , which [he]147-dick was weak enough to consider nothing better than death .

It is hard to live alone in the dark , confusing the day and night ; dropping to sleep through sheer weariness at mid - day , and rising restless in the chill of the dawn . At first [Dick]147-dick , on [his]147-dick awakenings , would grope along [the corridors of [the chambers]683-the chambers]682-the corridors of the chambers till [he]147-dick heard [some one snore]1723-some one snore . Then [he]147-dick would know that the day had not yet come , and return wearily to [[his]147-dick bedroom]1724-his bedroom .

Later [he]147-dick learned not to stir till there was a noise and movement in [the house]330-the house and [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton advised [him]147-dick to get up . Once dressed - and dressing , now that [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow was away , was a lengthy business , because collars , ties , and the like hid themselves in far corners of [the room]397-the room , and search meant head - beating against chairs and trunks - once dressed , there was nothing whatever to do except to sit still and brood till the three daily meals came . [Centuries]278-centuries separated breakfast from lunch and lunch from dinner , and though [a man]308-a man prayed for hundreds of years that [his]308-a man mind might be taken from [him]308-a man , [God]161-god would never hear . Rather the mind was quickened and the revolving thoughts ground against each other as millstones grind when there is no corn between ; and yet the brain would not wear out and give [him]308-a man rest . [It]1728-it continued to think , at length , with imagery and all manner of reminiscences . [It]1728-it recalled [Maisie]146-maisie and past success , reckless travels by [land]3013-land and [sea]1016-sea , the glory of doing work and feeling that it was good , and suggested all that might have happened had the eyes only been faithful to [their]1731-their duty . When thinking ceased through sheer weariness , there poured into [Dick]147-dick 's soul tide on tide of overwhelming , purposeless fear - dread of starvation always , terror lest the unseen ceiling should crush down upon [him]147-dick , fear of fire in [the chambers]683-the chambers and a louse 's death in red flame , and agonies of fiercer horror that had nothing to do with any fear of death . Then [Dick]147-dick bowed [his]147-dick head , and clutching the arms of [his]147-dick chair fought with [his]147-dick sweating self till the tinkle of plates told [him]147-dick that something to eat was being set before [him]147-dick .

[Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton would bring the meal when [he]189-mr. beeton had time to spare , and [Dick]147-dick learned to hang upon [his]147-dick speech , which dealt with badly fitted gas - plugs , waste - pipes out of repair , little tricks for driving picture - nails into walls , and the sins of [the charwoman]1733-the charwoman or [the housemaids]1734-the housemaids . In the lack of better things the small gossip of [[a servant]1735-a servant 's hall]1736-a servant 's hall becomes immensely interesting , and the screwing of [a washer on a tap]1737-a washer on a tap an event to be talked over for days .

Once or twice a week , too , [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton would take [Dick]147-dick out with [him]189-mr. beeton when [he]189-mr. beeton went marketing in the morning to haggle with [tradesmen]1738-tradesmen over fish , lamp - wicks , mustard , tapioca , and so forth , while [Dick]147-dick rested [his]147-dick weight first on one foot and then on the other and played aimlessly with the tins and string - ball on the counter . Then [they]1739-they would perhaps meet [one of [[Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton 's friends]1741-mr. beeton 's friends]1740-one of mr. beeton 's friends , and [Dick]147-dick , standing aside a little , would hold [his]147-dick peace till [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton was willing to go on again .

The life did not increase [his]147-dick self - respect . [He]147-dick abandoned shaving as a dangerous exercise , and being shaved in [[a barber]1742-a barber 's shop]1743-a barber 's shop meant exposure of [his]147-dick infirmity . [He]147-dick could not see that [his]147-dick clothes were properly brushed , and since [he]147-dick had never taken any care of [his]147-dick personal appearance [he]147-dick became every known variety of sloven . [A blind man]1744-a blind man can not deal with cleanliness till [he]1744-a blind man has been some months used to the darkness . If [he]1744-a blind man demand attendance and grow angry at the want of it , [he]1744-a blind man must assert [himself]1744-a blind man and stand upright . Then [the meanest menial]1745-the meanest menial can see that [he]1744-a blind man is blind and , therefore , of no consequence . [A wise man]1746-a wise man will keep [his]1746-a wise man eyes on the floor and sit still . For amusement [he]1746-a wise man may pick coal lump by lump out of the scuttle with the tongs and pile it in a little heap in the fender , keeping count of the lumps , which must all be put back again , one by one and very carefully . [He]147-dick may set [himself]147-dick sums if [he]147-dick cares to work them out ; [he]147-dick may talk to [himself]147-dick or to the cat if [she]1747-she chooses to visit [him]147-dick ; and if [his]147-dick trade has been that of [an artist]2183-an artist , [he]147-dick may sketch in the air with [his]147-dick forefinger ; but that is too much like drawing [a pig with the eyes shut]1749-a pig with the eyes shut . [He]147-dick may go to [his]147-dick bookshelves and count [his]147-dick books , ranging them in order of their size ; or to [his]147-dick wardrobe and count [his]147-dick shirts , laying them in piles of two or three on the bed , as they suffer from frayed cuffs or lost buttons .

Even this entertainment wearies after a time ; and all the times are very , very long .

[Dick]147-dick was allowed to sort a tool - chest where [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton kept hammers , taps and nuts , lengths of gas - pipes , oil - bottles , and string .

' If [I]189-mr. beeton do n't have everything just where [I]189-mr. beeton know where to look for it , why , then , [I]189-mr. beeton ca n't find anything when [I]189-mr. beeton do want it . [You]147-dick 've no idea , [sir]2295-sir , the amount of little things that [these chambers]3181-these chambers uses up , '[189-mr. beeton] said [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton .

Fumbling at the handle of the door as [he]189-mr. beeton went out : ' It 's hard on [you]2295-sir , [sir]2295-sir , [I]189-mr. beeton do think it 's hard on [you]2295-sir . Ai n't [you]2295-sir going to do anything , [sir]2295-sir ? '[189-mr. beeton]

' [I]189-mr. beeton 'll pay [my]189-mr. beeton rent and messing . Is n't that enough ? '[189-mr. beeton]

' [I]189-mr. beeton was n't doubting for a moment that [you]2295-sir could n't pay [your]2295-sir way , [sir]2295-sir ; but [I]189-mr. beeton '[189-mr. beeton] ave often said to [[my]0-i wife]1750-my wife , " It 's ' ard on '[0-i] [i]0-i m because it is n't as if [he]1751-he was [an old man]1752-an old man , nor yet [a middle - aged one]1753-a middle - aged one , but quite [a young gentleman]1754-a young gentleman . That 's where it comes so ' ard . " '[189-mr. beeton]

' [I]147-dick suppose so , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , absently . This particular nerve through long battering had ceased to feel - much .

' [I]189-mr. beeton was thinking , '[189-mr. beeton] continued [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton , still making as if to go , ' that [you]147-dick might like to hear [[my]189-mr. beeton boy]2818-my boy [Alf]279-alf read [you]147-dick the papers sometimes of an evening . [He]279-alf do read beautiful , seeing [he]279-alf 's only nine . '[189-mr. beeton]

' [I]147-dick should be very grateful , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick . ' Only let [me]147-dick make it worth [his]1751-he while . '[147-dick]

' [We]3186-we was n't thinking of that , [sir]2295-sir , but of course it 's in [your]147-dick own '[189-mr. beeton] ands ; but only to ' ear [Alf]279-alf sing " [[A Boy]1589-a boy 's best Friend]3189-a boy 's best friend is '[147-dick] is [Mother]280-mother ! " Ah ! '[280-mother]

' [I]279-alf 'll hear [him]279-alf sing that too . Let [him]279-alf come this evening with the newspapers . '[279-alf]

[Alf]279-alf was not [a nice child]1755-a nice child , being puffed up with many school - board certificates for good conduct , and inordinately proud of [his]279-alf singing . [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton remained , beaming , while [the child]802-the child wailed [his]802-the child way through a song of some eight eight - line verses in the usual whine of [a young Cockney]1757-a young cockney , and , after compliments , left [him]279-alf to read [Dick]147-dick the foreign telegrams . Ten minutes later [Alf]279-alf returned to [[his]279-alf parents]1758-his parents rather pale and scared .

" [E]1759-e said ' [e]1759-e could n't stand it no more , '[279-alf] [he]279-alf explained .

' [He]1759-e never said [you]279-alf read badly , [Alf]279-alf ? '[281-mrs. beeton] [Mrs. Beeton]281-mrs. beeton spoke .

' No . '[1759-e] [E]1759-e said [I]0-i read beautiful . Said ' [e]1759-e never '[281-mrs. beeton] eard [any one]2547-any one read like that , but ' [e]1759-e said '[1759-e] [e]1759-e could n't abide the stuff in the papers . '[1759-e]

' P'raps [he]1759-e 's lost some money in the Stocks . Were [you]279-alf readin '[281-mrs. beeton] [him]1759-e about Stocks , [Alf]279-alf ? '[281-mrs. beeton]

' No ; it was all about fightin '[1759-e] out there where [the soldiers]436-the soldiers is gone - a great long piece with all the lines close together and very hard words in it . ' [E]1759-e give [me]1759-e '[1759-e] arf a crown because [I]0-i read so well . And ' [e]1759-e says the next time there 's anything '[1759-e] [e]1759-e wants read ' [e'll]1759-e send for [me]1759-e . '[1759-e]

' That 's good hearing , but [I]368-the boy do think for all the half - crown - put it into the kicking - donkey money - box , [Alf]279-alf , and let [me]368-the boy see [you]279-alf do it - [he]1759-e might have kept [you]279-alf longer . Why , [he]1759-e could n't have begun to understand how beautiful [you]279-alf read . '[368-the boy]

' [He]1759-e 's best left to [hisself]3190-hisself - [gentlemen]1322-gentlemen always are when [they]1322-gentlemen 're[1759-e] downhearted , ' said [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton .[1759-e]

[Alf]279-alf 's rigorously limited powers of comprehending [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's special correspondence had waked the devil of unrest in [Dick]147-dick . [He]147-dick could hear , through [the boy]368-the boy 's nasal chant , the camels grunting in the squares behind [the soldiers outside [Suakin]13-suakin]1763-the soldiers outside suakin ; could hear [the men]528-the men swearing and chaffing across the cooking pots , and could smell the acrid wood - smoke as it drifted over camp before the wind of [the desert]416-the desert .

That night [he]147-dick prayed to [God]161-god that [his]147-dick mind might be taken from [him]147-dick , offering for proof that [he]147-dick was worthy of this favour the fact that [he]147-dick had not shot [himself]147-dick long ago . That prayer was not answered , and indeed [Dick]147-dick knew in [his]147-dick heart of hearts that only a lingering sense of humour and no special virtue had kept [him]147-dick alive . Suicide , [he]147-dick had persuaded [himself]147-dick , would be a ludicrous insult to the gravity of the situation as well as a weak - kneed confession of fear .

' Just for the fun of the thing , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said to the cat , who had taken [Binkie]180-binkie 's place in [[his]147-dick establishment]1766-his establishment , ' [I]147-dick should like to know how long this is going to last . [I]147-dick can live for a year on the hundred pounds [Torp]167-torp cashed for [me]147-dick . [I]147-dick must have two or three thousand at least in [the Bank]795-the bank - twenty or thirty years more provided for , that is to say . Then [I]147-dick fall back on [my]147-dick hundred and twenty a year , which will be more by that time . Let 's consider .[147-dick]

Twenty - five - thirty - five - [a man]308-a man 's in [his]308-a man prime then , [they]1768-they say - forty - five - [a middle - aged man just entering politics]1769-a middle - aged man just entering politics - fifty - five - " died at the comparatively early age of fifty - five , " according to the newspapers . Bah ! How [these Christians]1770-these christians funk death ! Sixty - five - [we]1771-we 're only getting on in years . Seventy - five is just possible , though . Great hell , cat O ! fifty years more of solitary confinement in the dark ! [You]3193-you 'll die , and [Beeton]189-mr. beeton will die , and [Torp]167-torp will die , and [Mai]282-mai - [everybody else]3194-everybody else will die , but [I]1768-they shall be alive and kicking with nothing to do . [I]1768-they 'm[1768-they] very sorry for [myself]0-i . [I]0-i should like [some one else]2792-some one else to be sorry for [me]0-i . Evidently [I]0-i 'm not going mad before [I]1768-they die , but the pain 's just as bad as ever . Some day when [you]1773-you 're[1768-they] vivisected , cat O ! [they]1768-they 'll tie [you]1773-you down on a little table and cut [you]1773-you open - but do n't be afraid ; [they]1768-they 'll take precious good care that [you]1773-you do n't die . [You]1773-you 'll live , and [you]1773-you 'll be very sorry then that [you]1773-you were n't sorry for [me]0-i . Perhaps [Torp]167-torp will come back or ... [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could go to [Torp]167-torp and [the Nilghai]2383-the nilghai , even though [I]0-i were in [their]1768-they way . '[283-pussy]

[Pussy]283-pussy left [the room]397-the room before the speech was ended , and [Alf]279-alf , as [he]279-alf entered , found [Dick]147-dick addressing the empty hearth - rug .

' There 's a letter for [you]279-alf , [sir]2295-sir , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said . ' Perhaps [you]279-alf 'd like [me]147-dick to read it . '[147-dick]

' Lend it to [me]279-alf for a minute and [I]279-alf 'll tell [you]279-alf . '[279-alf]

The outstretched hand shook just a little and the voice was not over - steady . It was within the limits of human possibility that - that was no letter from [Maisie]146-maisie . [He]279-alf knew the heft of three closed envelopes only too well . It was a foolish hope that [the girl]345-the girl should write to [him]279-alf , for [he]279-alf did not realise that there is a wrong which admits of no reparation though [the evildoer]1777-the evildoer may with tears and the heart 's best love strive to mend all . It is best to forget that wrong whether it be caused or endured , since it is as remediless as bad work once put forward .

' Read it , then , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , and [Alf]279-alf began intoning according to the rules of [the Board School]1778-the board school - ' " [I]279-alf could have given [you]279-alf love , [I]279-alf could have given [you]279-alf loyalty , such as [you]279-alf never dreamed of . Do [you]279-alf suppose [I]279-alf cared what [you]279-alf were ? But [you]279-alf chose to whistle everything down the wind for nothing . [My]279-alf only excuse for [you]279-alf is that [you]279-alf are so young . " '[279-alf] That 's all , ' [he]279-alf said , returning the paper to be dropped into the fire .[279-alf]

' What was in the letter ? '[281-mrs. beeton] asked [Mrs. Beeton]281-mrs. beeton , when [Alf]279-alf returned .

' [I]279-alf do n't know . [I]279-alf think it was a circular or a tract about not whistlin '[279-alf] at everything when [you]279-alf 're young . '[279-alf]

' [I]0-i must have stepped on something when [I]0-i was alive and walking about and it has bounced up and hit [me]0-i . God help it , whatever it is - unless it was all a joke . [I]0-i wonder whether [I]0-i have lost anything really ? '[0-i]

[Dick]147-dick considered for a long time but could not remember when or how [he]147-dick had put [himself]147-dick in the way of winning these trifles at [a woman]730-a woman 's hands .

Still , the letter as touching on matters that [he]147-dick preferred not to think about stung [him]147-dick into a fit of frenzy that lasted for a day and night . When [his]147-dick heart was so full of despair that it would hold no more , body and soul together seemed to be dropping without check through the darkness .

Then came fear of darkness and desperate attempts to reach the light again . But there was no light to be reached . When that agony had left [him]147-dick sweating and breathless , the downward flight would recommence till the gathering torture of it spurred [him]147-dick into another fight as hopeless as the first . Followed some few minutes of sleep in which [he]147-dick dreamed that [he]147-dick saw . Then the procession of events would repeat itself till [he]147-dick was utterly worn out and the brain took up its everlasting consideration of [Maisie]146-maisie and [might - have - beens]1780-might - have - beens .

At the end of everything [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton came to [[his]147-dick room]685-his room and volunteered to take [him]147-dick out . ' Not marketing this time , but [we]3197-we 'll go into [the Parks]1673-the parks if [you]147-dick like . '[189-mr. beeton]

This was not altogether true . [Her]244-bessie eyes fell on [Dick]147-dick opposite [her]244-bessie and [she]244-bessie was both shocked and displeased . Twenty - two pounds covers [my]0-i passage [home]2172-home again . Allow ten for additional expenses . [We]1900-i must put up at Madam Binat 's for old time 's sake . Thirty - two pounds altogether . Add a hundred for the cost of the last trip - Gad , wo n't [Torp]167-torp stare to see [me]0-i ! - a hundred and thirty - two leaves seventy - eight for baksheesh - [I]0-i shall need it - and to play with .

What are [you]244-bessie crying for , [Bess]255-bess ? It was n't [your]244-bessie fault , [child]1649-child ; it was mine altogether . Oh , [you]244-bessie funny little opossum , mop [your]244-bessie eyes and take [me]0-i out !

[I]0-i want the pass - book and the check - book . Stop a minute . Four thousand pounds at four per cent - that 's safe interest - means a hundred and sixty pounds a year ; one hundred and twenty pounds a year - also safe - is two eighty , and two hundred and eighty pounds added to three hundred a year means gilded luxury for [a single woman]1902-a single woman . [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton addressed [Dick]147-dick soothingly , but it was some time before [the latter]487-the latter , threshing up and down [[his]147-dick bedroom]1724-his bedroom , could realise the intention of the promises to ' find everything to - morrow , [sir]2295-sir . '[487-the latter]

' Oh , [[you]147-dick copper - nosed old fool]3293-you copper - nosed old fool - [[you]147-dick impotent Academician]3294-you impotent academician !
