If [you]147-dick touch it , it will go off , because it 's loaded .[189-mr. beeton]

It 's among [my]0-i campaign - kit somewhere - in the parcel at the bottom of the trunk . '[189-mr. beeton]

Long ago [Dick]147-dick had carefully possessed [himself]147-dick of a forty - pound weight field - equipment constructed by the knowledge of [his]147-dick own experience . It was this put - away treasure that [he]147-dick was trying to find and rehandle . [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton whipped the revolver out of its place on the top of the package , and [Dick]147-dick drove [his]147-dick hand among the khaki coat and breeches , the blue cloth leg - bands , and the heavy flannel shirts doubled over a pair of swan - neck spurs . Under these and the water - bottle lay a sketch - book and a pigskin case of stationery .

' These [we]3295-we do n't want ; [you]147-dick can have them , [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton . Everything else [I]0-i 'll keep . Pack 'em[0-i] on the top right - hand side of [[my]0-i trunk]1925-my trunk . When [you]147-dick 've done that come into [the studio]712-the studio with [[your]147-dick wife]1927-your wife . [I]0-i want [you]147-dick both . Wait a minute ; get [me]0-i a pen and a sheet of notepaper . '[0-i]

It is not an easy thing to write when [you]1928-you can not see , and [Dick]147-dick had particular reasons for wishing that [his]147-dick work should be clear . So [he]147-dick began , following [his]147-dick right hand with [his]147-dick left : ' " The badness of this writing is because [I]147-dick am blind and can not see [my]147-dick pen . " H'mph ! - even [a lawyer]3296-a lawyer ca n't mistake that . It must be signed , [I]147-dick suppose , but it need n't be witnessed . Now an inch lower - why did [I]147-dick never learn to use [a type - writer]3297-a type - writer ? - " This is the last will and testament of [me]147-dick , [Richard Heldar]287-richard heldar . [I]147-dick am in sound bodily and mental health , and there is no previous will to revoke . " - That 's all right . Damn the pen ! Whereabouts on the paper was [I]147-dick ? - " [I]147-dick leave everything that [I]147-dick possess in [the world]327-the world , including four thousand pounds , and two thousand seven hundred and twenty eight pounds held for [me]147-dick " - oh , [I]147-dick ca n't get this straight . '[147-dick] [He]147-dick tore off half the sheet and began again with the caution about the handwriting . Then : ' [I]147-dick leave all the money [I]147-dick possess in [the world]327-the world to '[147-dick] - here followed [Maisie]146-maisie 's name , and the names of the two banks that held the money .

' It may n't be quite regular , but [no one]2414-no one has a shadow of a right to dispute it , and [I]147-dick 've given [Maisie]146-maisie 's address . Come in , [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton . This is [my]147-dick signature ; [I]147-dick want [you]189-mr. beeton and [[your]189-mr. beeton wife]1927-your wife to witness it . Thanks . To - morrow [you]189-mr. beeton must take [me]147-dick to [the landlord]3302-the landlord and [I]147-dick 'll pay forfeit for leaving without notice , and [I]147-dick 'll lodge this paper with [him]3302-the landlord in case anything happens while [I]147-dick 'm[147-dick] away . Now [we]1929-we 're going to light up the studio stove . Stay with [me]147-dick , and give [me]147-dick [my]147-dick papers as [I]147-dick want 'em[147-dick] . '[147-dick]

[No one]2414-no one knows until [he]1931-he has tried how fine a blaze a year 's accumulation of bills , letters , and dockets can make . [Dick]147-dick stuffed into the stove every document in [the studio]712-the studio - saving only three unopened letters ; destroyed sketch - books , rough note - books , new and half - finished canvases alike .

' What a lot of rubbish [a tenant]3303-a tenant gets about [him]3303-a tenant if [he]3303-a tenant stays long enough in one place , to be sure , '[189-mr. beeton] said [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton , at last .

' [He]3303-a tenant does . Is there anything more left ? '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick felt round the walls .

' Not a thing , and the stove 's nigh red - hot . '[147-dick]

' Excellent , and [you]147-dick 've lost about a thousand pounds '[189-mr. beeton] worth of sketches .

Ho ! ho ! Quite a thousand pounds ' worth , if [I]147-dick can remember what [I]147-dick used to be . '[147-dick]

' Yes , [sir]2295-sir , '[147-dick] politely . [Mr. Beeton]189-mr. beeton was quite sure that [Dick]147-dick had gone mad , otherwise [he]147-dick would have never parted with [his]147-dick excellent furniture for a song . The canvas things took up [storage room]1933-storage room and were much better out of the way .

There remained only to leave the little will in safe hands : that could not be accomplished till to - morrow . [Dick]147-dick groped about the floor picking up the last pieces of paper , assured [himself]147-dick again and again that there remained no written word or sign of [his]147-dick past life in drawer or desk , and sat down before the stove till the fire died out and the contracting iron cracked in the silence of the night .

CHAPTER XV

With a heart of furious fancies , Whereof [I]0-i am [commander]1934-commander ; With a burning spear and a horse of air , To [the wilderness [I]0-i wander]1935-the wilderness i wander .

With [a knight of ghosts and shadows]1936-a knight of ghosts and shadows [I]0-i summoned am to tourney - [Ten leagues beyond [the wide world]2433-the wide world 's end]1937-ten leagues beyond the wide world 's end , Methinks it is no journey .

- [Tom a ' Bedlam]191-tom 's Song . '[191-tom] GOOD - BYE , [Bess]255-bess ; [I]0-i promised [you]255-bess fifty . [Here]2226-here 's a hundred - all that [I]0-i got for [my]0-i furniture from [Beeton]189-mr. beeton . That will keep [you]255-bess in pretty frocks for some time . [You]255-bess 've been [a good little girl]1940-a good little girl , all things considered , but [you]255-bess 've given [me]0-i and [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow a fair amount of trouble . '[255-bess]

' Give [Mr. Torpenhow]156-torpenhow [my]255-bess love if [you]255-bess see [him]156-torpenhow , wo n't [you]255-bess ? '[255-bess]

' Of course [I]255-bess will , [dear]2419-dear . Now take [me]255-bess up [the gang - plank]3306-the gang - plank and into [the cabin]3307-the cabin . Once aboard [the lugger]3308-the lugger and [the maid]3309-the maid is - and [I]255-bess am free , [I]255-bess mean . '[255-bess]

' Who 'll look after [you]255-bess on [this ship]3310-this ship ? '[255-bess]

' [The head - steward]3311-the head - steward , if there 's any use in money . [The doctor]579-the doctor when [we]3313-we come to [Port Said]36-port said , if [I]255-bess know anything of [P.]288-p. and [O. doctors]3314-o. doctors . After that , [the Lord]2330-the lord will provide , as [He]147-dick used to do . '[255-bess]

[Bess]255-bess found [Dick]147-dick [[his]147-dick cabin]1941-his cabin in the wild turmoil of [a ship full of [leavetakers]1943-leavetakers]1942-a ship full of leavetakers and [weeping relatives]1944-weeping relatives . Then [he]147-dick kissed [her]255-bess , and laid [himself]147-dick down in [his]147-dick bunk until [the decks]1945-the decks should be clear . [[He]147-dick who had taken so long to move about [[his]147-dick own darkened rooms]1947-his own darkened rooms]1946-he who had taken so long to move about his own darkened rooms well understood the geography of [a ship]2853-a ship , and the necessity of seeing to [his]147-dick own comforts was as wine to [him]147-dick .

Before the screw began to thrash [the ship]2756-the ship along [the Docks]660-the docks [he]147-dick had been introduced to [the head - steward]3311-the head - steward , had royally tipped [him]147-dick , secured a good place at table , opened out [his]147-dick baggage , and settled [himself]147-dick down with joy in [the cabin]3307-the cabin . It was scarcely necessary to feel [his]147-dick way as [he]147-dick moved about , for [he]147-dick knew everything so well . Then [God]161-god was very kind : a deep sleep of weariness came upon [him]147-dick just as [he]147-dick would have thought of [Maisie]146-maisie , and [he]147-dick slept till [the steamer]1278-the steamer had cleared [the mouth of [the Thames]41-the thames]1954-the mouth of the thames and was lifting to the pulse of [the Channel]129-the channel .

The rattle of the engines , the reek of oil and paint , and a very familiar sound in [the next cabin]1955-the next cabin roused [him]147-dick to [his]147-dick new inheritance .

' Oh , it 's good to be alive again ! '[147-dick] [He]147-dick yawned , stretched [himself]147-dick vigorously , and went on [deck]1956-deck to be told that [they]1957-they were almost abreast of the lights of [Brighton]43-brighton . This is [no more open water]1958-no more open water than [Trafalgar Square]73-trafalgar square is a common ; the free levels begin at [Ushant]83-ushant ; but none the less [Dick]147-dick could feel the healing of [the sea]2168-the sea at work upon [him]147-dick already . A boisterous little cross - swell swung [the steamer]1278-the steamer disrespectfully by the nose ; and one wave breaking far aft spattered [the quarterdeck]1961-the quarterdeck and the pile of new deck - chairs . [He]147-dick heard the foam fall with the clash of broken glass , was stung in the face by a cupful , and sniffing luxuriously , felt [his]147-dick way to [the smoking - room by the wheel]1962-the smoking - room by the wheel . There a strong breeze found [him]147-dick , blew [his]147-dick cap off and left [him]147-dick bareheaded in the doorway , and [the smoking - room steward]1963-the smoking - room steward , understanding that [he]147-dick was [a voyager of experience]1964-a voyager of experience , said that the weather would be stiff in the chops off [the Channel]129-the channel and more than half a gale in [the Bay]131-the bay . These things fell as they were foretold , and [Dick]147-dick enjoyed [himself]147-dick to the utmost . It is allowable and even necessary at [sea]1016-sea to lay firm hold upon tables , stanchions , and ropes in moving from place to place . On [land]3013-land [the man who feels with]1967-the man who feels with [his]1967-the man who feels with hands is patently blind . At [sea]1016-sea even [a blind man who is not sea - sick]1969-a blind man who is not sea - sick can jest with [the doctor]579-the doctor over the weakness of [[his]1969-a blind man who is not sea - sick fellows]2841-his fellows . [Dick]147-dick told [the doctor]579-the doctor many tales - and these are coin of more value than silver if properly handled - smoked with [him]579-the doctor till unholy hours of the night , and so won [his]579-the doctor short - lived regard that [he]579-the doctor promised [Dick]147-dick a few hours of [his]147-dick time when [they]1973-they came to [Port Said]36-port said .

And [the sea]2168-the sea roared or was still as the winds blew , and the engines sang [their]1975-their song day and night , and the sun grew stronger day by day , and [Tom the Lascar]289-tom the lascar barber shaved [Dick]147-dick of a morning under the opened hatch - grating where the cool winds blew , and the awnings were spread and [the passengers]2765-the passengers made merry , and at last [they]1973-they came to [Port Said]36-port said .

' Take [me]147-dick , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , to [the doctor]579-the doctor , ' to [Madame Binat]162-madame 's - if [you]579-the doctor know where that is . '[147-dick]

' Whew ! '[579-the doctor] said [the doctor]579-the doctor , ' [I]579-the doctor do . There 's not much to choose between 'em[579-the doctor] ; but [I]0-i suppose [you]147-dick 're aware that that 's [one of [the worst houses in [the place]700-the place]3317-the worst houses in the place]3316-one of the worst houses in the place . [They]3319-they 'll rob [you]147-dick to begin with , and knife [you]147-dick later . '[147-dick]

' Not [they]3319-they . Take [me]0-i [there]2480-there , and [I]0-i can look after [myself]0-i . '[0-i]

So [he]147-dick was brought to [[Madame Binat]162-madame 's]1979-madame binat 's and filled [his]147-dick nostrils with the well - remembered smell of [the East]1980-the east , that runs without a change from the Canal head to [Hong - Kong]132-hong - kong , and [his]147-dick mouth with [the villainous Lingua Franca of [the Levant]133-the levant]1981-the villainous lingua franca of the levant . The heat smote [him]147-dick between the shoulder - blades with the buffet of [an old friend]1982-an old friend , [his]147-dick feet slipped on the sand , and [his]147-dick coat - sleeve was warm as new - baked bread when [he]147-dick lifted it to [his]147-dick nose .

[Madame Binat]162-madame smiled with the smile that knows no astonishment when [Dick]147-dick entered [the drinking - shop]1983-the drinking - shop which was one source of [her]162-madame gains . But for a little accident of complete darkness [he]147-dick could hardly realise that [he]147-dick had ever quitted the old life that hummed in [his]147-dick ears . [Somebody]575-somebody opened a bottle of peculiarly strong Schiedam . The smell reminded [Dick]147-dick of [Monsieur Binat]163-monsieur binat , who , by the way , had spoken of art and degradation .

[Binat]163-monsieur binat was dead ; [Madame]162-madame said as much when [the doctor]579-the doctor departed , scandalised , so far as [[a ship]2853-a ship 's doctor]1987-a ship 's doctor can be , at the warmth of [Dick]147-dick 's reception . [Dick]147-dick was delighted at it . ' [They]3321-they remember [me]147-dick here after a year . [They]3321-they have forgotten [me]147-dick across [the water]434-the water by this time . [Madame]162-madame , [I]147-dick want a long talk with [you]162-madame when [you]162-madame 're[147-dick] at liberty . It is good to be back again . '[162-madame]

In the evening [she]162-madame set an iron - topped cafe - table out on [the sands]440-the sands , and [Dick]147-dick and [she]162-madame sat by it , while [the house]330-the house behind [them]1990-we filled with riot , merriment , oaths , and threats . The stars came out and the lights of the shipping in [the harbour]1991-the harbour twinkled by the head of [the Canal]134-the canal .

' Yes . The war is good for trade , [[my]231-tina friend]2928-my friend ; but what dost [thou]3324-thou do here ? [We]1990-we have not forgotten [thee]3324-thou . '[231-tina]

' [I]231-tina was over [there]2480-there in [England]18-england and [I]231-tina went blind . '[231-tina]

' But there was the glory first . [We]1990-we heard of it here , even here - [I]231-tina and [Binat]162-madame ; and [thou]3324-thou hast used the head of [Yellow]230-yellow '[231-tina] [Tina]231-tina - [she]231-tina is still alive - so often and so well that ' [Tina]231-tina laughed when the papers arrived by [the mail - boats]3326-the mail - boats . It was always something that [we]1990-we here could recognise in the paintings . And then there was always the glory and the money for [thee]3324-thou . '[231-tina]

' [I]231-tina am not poor - [I]231-tina shall pay [you]231-tina well . '[231-tina]

' Not to [me]231-tina . [Thou]3324-thou hast paid for everything . '[231-tina] Under [her]231-tina breath , ' [Mon Dieu]290-mon dieu , to be blind and so young ! What horror ! '[231-tina]

[Dick]147-dick could not see [her]231-tina face with the pity on it , or [his]147-dick own with the discoloured hair at the temples . [He]147-dick did not feel the need of pity ; [he]147-dick was too anxious to get to the front once more , and explained [his]147-dick desire .

' And where ? [The Canal]639-the canal is full of [the English ships]3328-the english ships . Sometimes [they]3328-the english ships fire as [they]3328-the english ships used to do when the war was here - ten years ago . [Dick]147-dick stretched [himself]147-dick on the floor , wild with delight at the sounds and the smells .

' [God]161-god is very good - [I]147-dick never thought [I]147-dick 'd hear this again . Give 'em[147-dick] hell , [men]430-men . Oh , give 'em hell ! '[147-dick] [he]147-dick cried .

[The train]973-the train stopped for some obstruction on the line ahead and [a party]2073-a party went out to reconnoitre , but came back , cursing , for spades . [The children of [the desert]416-the desert]2062-the children of the desert had piled sand and gravel on the rails , and twenty minutes were lost in clearing [it]2076-it away . Then the slow progress recommenced , to be varied with more shots , more shoutings , the steady clack and kick of the machine guns , and a final difficulty with a half - lifted rail ere [the train]973-the train came under the protection of [the roaring camp at [Tanai - el - Hassan]140-tanai - el - hassan]2078-the roaring camp at tanai - el - hassan .

' Now , [you]147-dick see why it takes an hour and a half to fetch [her]3422-her through , '[2041-the subaltern] said [the subaltern]2041-the subaltern , unshipping the cartridge - hopper above [his]2041-the subaltern pet gun .

' It was a lark , though . [I]147-dick only wish it had lasted twice as long . How superb it must have looked from outside ! '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick , sighing regretfully .

' It palls after the first few nights . By the way , when [you]2082-you 've settled about [your]2082-you mules , come and see what [we]3423-we can find to eat in [[my]2080-bennil of the gunners tent]3424-my tent . '[2082-you]

But it was all dark to [Dick]147-dick . [He]147-dick could only smell the camels , the hay - bales , the cooking , the smoky fires , and the tanned canvas of [the tents]2084-the tents as [he]147-dick stood , where [he]147-dick had dropped from [the train]973-the train , shouting for [George]260-george . There was a sound of light - hearted kicking on the iron skin of [the rear trucks]2086-the rear trucks , with squealing and grunting . [George]260-george was unloading the mules .

The engine was blowing off steam nearly in [Dick]147-dick 's ear ; a cold wind of [the desert]416-the desert danced between [his]260-george legs ; [he]260-george was hungry , and felt tired and dirty - so dirty that [he]260-george tried to brush [his]260-george coat with [his]260-george hands . That was a hopeless job ; [he]260-george thrust [his]260-george hands into [his]260-george pockets and began to count over the many times that [he]260-george had waited in strange or remote places for [trains]2088-trains or camels , mules or horses , to carry [him]260-george to [his]260-george business . In those days [he]260-george could see - [few men]2089-few men more clearly - and the spectacle of [an armed camp at dinner under the stars]2090-an armed camp at dinner under the stars was an ever fresh pleasure to the eye . There was colour , light , and motion , without which [no man]420-no man has much pleasure in living . This night there remained for [him]260-george only one more journey through the darkness that never lifts to tell [a man]308-a man how far [he]308-a man has travelled . Then [he]260-george would grip [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's hand again - [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , who was alive and strong , and lived in the midst of the action that had once made the reputation of [a man called [Dick Heldar]147-dick]2093-a man called dick heldar : not in the least to be confused with [the blind , bewildered vagabond who seemed to answer to the same name]2094-the blind , bewildered vagabond who seemed to answer to the same name . Yes , [he]260-george would find [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow , and come as near to the old life as might be . Afterwards [he]260-george would forget everything : [Bessie]244-bessie , who had wrecked the Melancolia and so nearly wrecked [his]260-george life ; [Beeton]189-mr. beeton , who lived in [a strange unreal city]2095-a strange unreal city full of tin - tacks and gas - plugs and matters that [no men]2096-no men needed ; [that irrational being who had offered [him]260-george love and loyalty for nothing , but had not signed [her]2097-that irrational being who had offered him love and loyalty for nothing , but had not signed her name name]2097-that irrational being who had offered him love and loyalty for nothing , but had not signed her name ; and most of all [Maisie]146-maisie , who , from [her]146-maisie own point of view , was undeniably right in all [she]146-maisie did , but oh , at this distance , so tantalisingly fair .

[George]260-george 's hand on [his]260-george arm pulled [him]260-george back to the situation .

' And what now ? '[260-george] said [George]260-george .

' Oh yes of course . What now ? Take [me]260-george to [the camel - men]3425-the camel - men . Take [me]260-george to where [the scouts]3401-the scouts sit when [they]3401-the scouts come in from [the desert]416-the desert . [They]3401-the scouts sit by [their]3401-the scouts camels , and the camels eat grain out of a black blanket held up at the corners , and [the men]528-the men eat by [their]528-the men side just like camels . Take [me]260-george there ! '[260-george]

[The camp]3382-the camp was rough and rutty , and [Dick]147-dick stumbled many times over [the stumps of scrub]2099-the stumps of scrub . [The scouts]3401-the scouts were sitting by [their]3401-the scouts beasts , as [Dick]147-dick knew [they]3401-the scouts would . The light of the dung - fires flickered on [their]3401-the scouts bearded faces , and the camels bubbled and mumbled beside [them]3401-the scouts at rest . It was no part of [Dick]147-dick 's policy to go into [the desert]416-the desert with [a convoy of supplies]2102-a convoy of supplies . That would lead to impertinent questions , and since [a blind non - combatant]2103-a blind non - combatant is not needed at the front , [he]2103-a blind non - combatant would probably be forced to return to [Suakin]13-suakin .

[He]2103-a blind non - combatant must go up alone , and go immediately .

' Now for one last bluff - the biggest of all , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said . ' [Peace]298-peace be with [you]2103-a blind non - combatant , [brethren]3429-brethren ! '[147-dick] [The watchful George]2104-the watchful george steered [him]2103-a blind non - combatant to the circle of the nearest fire . The heads of [the camel - sheiks]2105-the camel - sheiks bowed gravely , and the camels , scenting [a European]2106-a european , looked sideways curiously like brooding hens , half ready to get to [their]2105-the camel - sheiks feet .

' A beast and [a driver]3430-a driver to go to the fighting line to - night , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick .

' [A Mulaid]3431-a mulaid ? '[2107-the best baggage - breed that he knew] said a voice , scornfully naming [the best baggage - breed that [he]147-dick knew]2107-the best baggage - breed that he knew .

' A Bisharin , '[147-dick] returned [Dick]147-dick , with perfect gravity . ' [A Bisharin without saddle - galls]3432-a bisharin without saddle - galls . Therefore no charge of thine , shock - head . '[147-dick]

Two or three minutes passed . Then - ' [We]3433-we be knee - haltered for the night . There is no going out from [the camp]3382-the camp . '[2108-the sheik]

' Not for money ? '[2108-the sheik]

' H'm ! Ah ! English money ? '[2108-the sheik]

Another depressing interval of silence .

' How much ? '[2108-the sheik]

' Twenty - five pounds English paid into the hand of [the driver]3435-the driver at [my]2108-the sheik journey 's end , and as much more into the hand of the camel - sheik here , to be paid when [the driver]3435-the driver returns . '[2108-the sheik]

This was royal payment , and [the sheik]2108-the sheik , who knew that [he]2108-the sheik would get [his]2108-the sheik commission on this deposit , stirred in [Dick]147-dick 's behalf .

' For scarcely one night 's journey - fifty pounds . Land and wells and good trees and [wives]2742-wives to make [a man]308-a man content for the rest of [his]308-a man days . Who speaks ? '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick .

' [I]2108-the sheik , '[2108-the sheik] said a voice . ' [I]2108-the sheik will go - but there is no going from [the camp]3382-the camp . '[2108-the sheik]

' [Fool]3440-fool ! [I]487-the latter know that a camel can break [his]308-a man knee - halter , and [the sentries]2211-the sentries do not fire if one goes in chase . Twenty - five pounds and another twenty - five pounds . But the beast must be [a good Bisharin]3442-a good bisharin ; [I]487-the latter will take no baggage - camel . '[487-the latter]

Then the bargaining began , and at the end of half an hour the first deposit was paid over to [the sheik]2108-the sheik , who talked in low tones to [the driver]3435-the driver .

[Dick]147-dick heard [the latter]487-the latter say : ' A little way out only . Any baggage - beast will serve . Am [I]487-the latter [a fool]2351-a fool to waste [my]487-the latter cattle for [a blind man]1744-a blind man ? '[487-the latter]

' And though [I]147-dick can not see '[147-dick] - [Dick]147-dick lifted [his]147-dick voice a little - ' yet [I]147-dick carry that which has six eyes , and [the driver]3435-the driver will sit before [me]147-dick . If [we]3446-we do not reach [the English troops]2027-the english troops in the dawn [he]3435-the driver will be dead . '[147-dick]

' But where , in [God]161-god 's name , are [the troops]600-the troops ? '[147-dick]

' Unless [thou]3449-thou knowest let [another man]2530-another man ride . Dost [thou]3449-thou know ? Remember it will be life or death to [thee]3449-thou . '[147-dick]

' [I]3435-the driver know , '[3435-the driver] said [the driver]3435-the driver , sullenly . ' Stand back from [my]3435-the driver beast . [I]3435-the driver am going to slip [him]3435-the driver . '[3435-the driver]

' Not so swiftly . [George]260-george , hold the camel 's head a moment . [I]147-dick want to feel [his]3435-the driver cheek . '[147-dick] The hands wandered over the hide till [they]2113-they found the branded half - circle that is the mark of [the Biharin]299-the biharin , the light - built riding - camel .

' That is well . Cut [this one]3451-this one loose . Remember no blessing of [God]161-god comes on those who try to cheat [the blind]3049-the blind . '[528-the men]

[The men]528-the men chuckled by the fires at [the camel - driver]2115-the camel - driver 's discomfiture . [He]2115-the camel - driver had intended to substitute [a slow , saddle - galled baggage - colt]2116-a slow , saddle - galled baggage - colt .

' Stand back ! '[727-one] [one]727-one shouted , lashing [the Biharin]299-the biharin under the belly with a quirt . [Dick]147-dick obeyed as soon as [he]147-dick felt the nose - string tighten in [his]147-dick hand , - and a cry went up , ' [Illaha]300-illaha ! Aho ! [He]299-the biharin is loose . '[260-george]

With a roar and a grunt [the Biharin]299-the biharin rose to [his]299-the biharin feet and plunged forward toward [the desert]416-the desert , [[his]299-the biharin driver]2119-his driver following with shouts and lamentation .

[George]260-george caught [Dick]147-dick 's arm and hurried [him]147-dick stumbling and tripping past [a disgusted sentry who was used to stampeding camels]2120-a disgusted sentry who was used to stampeding camels .

' What 's the row now ? '[260-george] [he]260-george cried .

' Every stitch of [my]147-dick kit on [that blasted dromedary]3453-that blasted dromedary , '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick answered , after the manner of [a common soldier]2121-a common soldier .

' Go on , and take care [your]147-dick throat 's not cut out side - [you]147-dick and [your]147-dick dromedary 's . '[147-dick]

The outcries ceased when the camel had disappeared behind [a hillock]2122-a hillock , and [[his]299-the biharin driver]2119-his driver had called [him]299-the biharin back and made [him]299-the biharin kneel down .

' [Mount]301-mount first , '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick . Then climbing into the second seat and gently screwing the pistol muzzle into the small of [[his]147-dick companion]1871-his companion 's back , ' Go on in [God]161-god 's name , and swiftly . A few minutes later [he]147-dick was shut up in a great silence , hardly broken by the creaking of the saddle and the soft pad of the tireless feet . [Dick]147-dick adjusted [himself]147-dick comfortably to the rock and pitch of the pace , girthed [his]147-dick belt tighter , and felt the darkness slide past . For an hour [he]147-dick was conscious only of the sense of rapid progress .

' [A good camel]3456-a good camel , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick said at last .

' [He]3456-a good camel was never underfed . [He]3456-a good camel is [my]3435-the driver own and clean bred , '[3435-the driver] [the driver]3435-the driver replied .

' Go on . '[3435-the driver]

[His]147-dick head dropped on [his]147-dick chest and [he]147-dick tried to think , but the tenor of [his]147-dick thoughts was broken because [he]147-dick was very sleepy . In the half doze in seemed that [he]147-dick was learning a punishment hymn at [Mrs. Jennett]148-mrs. jennett 's . [He]147-dick had committed some crime as bad as Sabbath - breaking , and [she]148-mrs. jennett had locked [him]147-dick up in [[his]147-dick bedroom]1724-his bedroom . But [he]147-dick could never repeat more than the first two lines of the hymn -

When [Israel]302-israel of [the Lord]2330-the lord believed Out of [the land of bondage]2128-the land of bondage came .

[He]147-dick said them over and over thousands of times . [The driver]3435-the driver turned in the saddle to see if there were any chance of capturing the revolver and ending the ride . [Dick]147-dick roused , struck [him]3435-the driver over the head with the butt , and stormed [himself]147-dick wide awake . [Somebody hidden in a clump of camel - thorn]2130-somebody hidden in a clump of camel - thorn shouted as the camel toiled up rising ground . A shot was fired , and the silence shut down again , bringing the desire to sleep . [Dick]147-dick could think no longer . [He]147-dick was too tired and stiff and cramped to do more than nod uneasily from time to time , waking with a start and punching [the driver]3435-the driver with the pistol .

' Is there a moon ? '[147-dick] [he]147-dick asked drowsily .

' [She]3457-her is near [her]3457-her setting . '[147-dick]

' [I]493-the man wish that [I]493-the man could see [her]3457-her . Halt the camel . At least let [me]493-the man hear the desert talk . '[493-the man]

[The man]493-the man obeyed . Out of the utter stillness came one breath of wind . It rattled the dead leaves of a shrub some distance away and ceased . A handful of dry earth detached itself from the edge of a rail trench and crumbled softly to the bottom .

' Go on . The night is very cold . '[147-dick]

[Those who have watched till the morning]2133-those who have watched till the morning know how the last hour before the light lengthens itself into many eternities . It seemed to [Dick]147-dick that [he]147-dick had never since the beginning of original darkness done anything at all save jolt through the air . Once in a thousand years [he]147-dick would finger the nailheads on the saddle - front and count them all carefully . Centuries later [he]147-dick would shift [his]147-dick revolver from [his]147-dick right hand to [his]147-dick left and allow the eased arm to drop down at [his]147-dick side . From the safe distance of [London]33-london [he]147-dick was watching [himself]147-dick thus employed , - watching critically . Yet whenever [he]147-dick put out [his]147-dick hand to the canvas that [he]147-dick might paint [the tawny yellow desert]2134-the tawny yellow desert under the glare of the sinking moon , the black shadow of a camel and [the two bowed figures atop]2135-the two bowed figures atop , that hand held a revolver and the arm was numbed from wrist to collar - bone . Moreover , [he]147-dick was in the dark , and could see no canvas of any kind whatever .

[The driver]3435-the driver grunted , and [Dick]147-dick was conscious of a change in the air .

' [I]147-dick smell the dawn , '[147-dick] [he]147-dick whispered .

' It is here , and yonder are [the troops]600-the troops . Have [I]147-dick done well ? '[147-dick]

The camel stretched out its neck and roared as there came down wind the pungent reek of camels in [the square]524-the square .

' Go on . [We]2138-we must get there swiftly . Go on . '[3435-the driver]

' [They]600-the troops are moving in [[their]600-the troops camp]3459-their camp . There is so much dust that [I]3435-the driver can not see what [they]600-the troops do . '[3435-the driver]

' Am [I]3435-the driver in better case ? Go forward . '[3435-the driver]

[They]2138-we could hear the hum of voices ahead , the howling and the bubbling of the beasts and the hoarse cries of [the soldiers girthing up for the day]2139-the soldiers girthing up for the day .

Two or three shots were fired .

' Is that at [us]2138-we ? Surely [they]600-the troops can see that [I]147-dick am English , '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick spoke angrily .

' Nay , it is from [the desert]416-the desert , '[3435-the driver] [the driver]3435-the driver answered , cowering in [his]3435-the driver saddle .

' Go forward , [[my]3435-the driver child]3461-my child ! Well it is that the dawn did not uncover [us]2138-we an hour ago . '[3435-the driver]

[The camel]2141-the camel headed straight for the column and the shots behind multiplied . [The children of [the desert]416-the desert]2062-the children of the desert had arranged that most uncomfortable of surprises , a dawn attack for [the English troops]2027-the english troops , and were getting [their]2062-the children of the desert distance by snap - shots at the only moving object without the square .

' What luck ! What stupendous and imperial luck ! '[147-dick] said [Dick]147-dick . ' It 's " just before the battle , [mother]3462-mother . " Oh , [God]161-god has been most good to [me]147-dick ![147-dick]

[A bearded man raking in the ashes of a fire]2149-a bearded man raking in the ashes of a fire for a light to [his]493-the man pipe moved very swiftly towards that cry , as the rearguard , facing about , began to fire at the puffs of smoke from [the hillocks]2150-the hillocks around . Gradually the scattered white cloudlets drew out into the long lines of banked white that hung heavily in the stillness of the dawn before [they]2151-they turned over wave - like and glided into [the valleys]2152-the valleys . [The soldiers in [the square]524-the square]2153-the soldiers in the square were coughing and swearing as [their]2153-the soldiers in the square own smoke obstructed [their]2153-the soldiers in the square view , and [they]2153-the soldiers in the square edged forward to get beyond [it]2155-it . [A wounded camel]2156-a wounded camel leaped to [its]2156-a wounded camel feet and roared aloud , the cry ending in a bubbling grunt . [Some one]1532-some one had cut [its]2156-a wounded camel throat to prevent confusion . Then came the thick sob of [a man]308-a man receiving [his]308-a man death - wound from a bullet ; then a yell of agony and redoubled firing .

There was no time to ask any questions .

' Get down , [man]2294-man ! Get down behind the camel ! '[156-torpenhow]

' No . Put [me]147-dick , [I]147-dick pray , in the forefront of the battle . '[147-dick] [Dick]147-dick turned [his]147-dick face to [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow and raised [his]147-dick hand to set [his]147-dick helmet straight , but , miscalculating the distance , knocked it off . [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow saw that [his]147-dick hair was gray on the temples , and that [his]156-torpenhow face was the face of [an old man]1752-an old man .

' Come down , [[you]147-dick damned fool]3467-you damned fool ! [Dickie]175-dickie , come off ! '[1752-an old man]

And [Dick]147-dick came obediently , but as a tree falls , pitching sideways from [the Bisharin]304-the bisharin 's saddle at [Torpenhow]156-torpenhow 's feet . [His]147-dick luck had held to the last , even to the crowning mercy of a kindly bullet through [his]147-dick head .

[Torpenhow]156-torpenhow knelt under the lee of the camel , with [Dick]147-dick 's body in [his]156-torpenhow arms .
